reviews.review:
Glorious confection of a palace. Here is a grand and elegant palace with gardens to match There are 168 fountains in the garden with lush gardening and gold statues.
They say it was designed to impress and it did

Beautiful palace and great gardens. The palace differs from many others in that sense that the interior is renovated with furniture etc. to resemble as much as possible it`s interior in the 18th and 19th centuries. And this makes it far more interesting than average old royal palaces in Europe.The gardens are great and the fountains are the top attraction there.Best in a warm beautiful summer day and coming with a hydrofoil vessel from the centre of StP.

History and Beauty. Peterhof is a castle started by Peter the Great, around 1712. It is situated at the Gulf of Finland on the Baltic Sea, demonstrating Peter's desire to have access to the Baltic for Russia. The gardens are immense and beautiful, but the real attraction is the set of fountains. These follow the original design of Peter, and the basic mechanisms have not been changed for over 300 years! When they are started, the theme music for St. Petersburg is played over loudspeakers, and the entire production is quite amazing.

Good but there is Better. Spent the day at Peterhof as an excursion off of our cruise ship. Guide was very good but you could not take any photos anywhere inside of the palace buildings. The tour was very fast paced with timers in the rooms to keep you walking through and guards urging you along. Very narrow roped off areas to walk through so there was no stopping and enjoying the exhibits and preserved areas. The Hermitage and Catherine's Palace are much better, but, if you have time, this is worth a trip. Outside gardens and statues are magnificent.
Stunning. This place is splendour personified. The fountains are sensational. I feel very privileged to have been here.

Briefly on Peterhof. It was built to compete with the Versailles Palace and gardens. So one will not only enjoy with its fantastic beauty, but also make your own decision on the result of this competition. All seasons are good for the visit, but on Summer one will also enjoy with the impressive fountains, and in early autumn (September-beg October) adds a fantastic vew of what is called here "The Golden Autumn" .

Excellent!. Briefly, Park And Gardens of Peterhof can be compared to Versailles (it was an idea of Peter 1 to make it better than Versailles in France). Peterhof is divided in two parks or gardens with a number of palaces and fountains. There are plenty of descriptions of this amazing place, I just want to give some advices:- visiting the Peterhof should be given a whole day and besides it should be a clear sunny day;- you should take some food and water with you, because prices inside are quite high;- the best and cheapest way to get there - by microbus from metro stations eigher «Балтийская» - № 404 or «Проспект Ветеранов» № 343, № 639-б or «Автово» № 224, № 300, №404, №424, № 424-А. It will cost about 70-80 rubles;- the ceremonial opening of the fountains in 11 hours;- there are a lot of jocular fountains, running under which you get wet, so don`t forget to take a change of clothes for children.That`s all. Hope it`ll help you. And, in my opinion Peterhof is absolutely fantastic place which you obligatorily must to see))

Monumental landscape. If you have any interest in gardens or landscape or just fancy a good stroll, the grounds of Peterhof are magnificent and very well restored, a good insight into Tsarist approaches to landscape and garden ornament. Over the top in the best Russian way.

Opulence and Gold in abundance. One of the great gardens of the World. Originally laid out by Peter the Great, making use of the natural slope of the land to incorporate abundant fountains. Many of the fountains include gold plated figures or motifs. The figure of Samson slaying the lion (representing Russia Defeating Sweden) is a highlight. The gardens and palace badly damaged by the Nazis during the Second World War. The garden also includes a small palace, Mon Plasir, which was the home of Peter the Great. Later Catherine the Great was incarcerated here, before she and her lover rode off to the Capital, killer her husband the Czar, and assumed a very long and fruitful role as the Czarina.

I can understand why there was a revolution.. Travel by hydrofoil (45 mins). Be by the canal just before 11 am, the start up of the fountains made tears come to my eyes. This is the most beautiful palace I have ever visited but it would be interesting to know how many people died just building it.I can understand why overshoes are provide to safeguard the floors but would have liked to have taken photos (my camera bag was locked away and I was given the key). After the palace visit just wander round the grounds, there are fountains everywhere. I defy you to stand by the fountain waterfall and not think it is unbelievable. You must visit.
Magnificence!. Feeling like you are royalty M this is magnificent! The gardens, the gold statues at the fountains, the views of the water and palace are just breathtaking.

Worth of a visit. One of the places you can visit again and again, and every time you wish to have a little more time to just enjoy the beauty of the park, fountains and the nice atmosphere. Watch out the pickpocket, that is a known problem there.

Worth a visit. This island is easily accessible although a little bit of a walk from some of the other main attractions. You get good views of the church going across the bridge, so plenty of photo opportunities. The area itself is very interesting, lots of tombs and stuff. Definitely a good place to go.
Check box for St Petersburg. This was build by Peter the great and is fashioned after Versailles. It had been expanded many time to what it is today. If you see one palace you see them all.

lovely for a nice weather day. We were here during the summer in a particulary nice sunny week, so this place was just spectacular and we were even feeling like the approx 3 hour visit that had be arranged as a part of the tour was not enough to enjoy this place, we knew what kind of place it was but really if you can go from one garden to another, then relax at some spots, walk a little more, stop at a fountain, admire the views, take tons of photos and walk some more get into the crowded areas or away from them as you wish... time really goes by and you just dont seem to notice because it is so nice to be here! there are restrooms, with long lines but they move fast so you do not wait in a queue for long....there are some dressed up people by the big fountains offering to take a photo with you, which they quickly print right away and it turns out pretty good, and it is cheap I think 5 euros, And really neat if you want a quick souvenir...but they too let you take pics with your camera if you want...we were there in the afternoon and it was perfect cause it wasnt too hot. beautiful and worth a not so short visit.

Be prepared for crowds!. This was my second visit to Peterhof and I was lucky enough to arrive at 11 am- just when they turn the fountains on as the anthem of St Petersburg is played. I visited 3 years ago but I think this visit had even more tourists than previously. The line was long but having a private guide got our group of 4 through quickly. The tour through the Palace is regulated but very tightly packed! Afterwards, the stroll through the lower gardens was much more pleasant and the beauty unbelievable. Well worth the crowds and plan to spend 2 hours to thoroughly enjoy it.

Simply Breathtaking. Just Grand. Most beautiful gardens and fountains. Every thing in this huge palace is a masterpiece and amazingly awesome. Most impressive architecture and items of Tsar opulence. Must see for any tourist visiting Central Europe.

The Fountains Are The Thing. Certainly a grand palace, but the star here are the fountains and the gardens. At precisely 11:00 AM each day the fountains are turned on to the accompaniment of grand music. Find yourself a good location above or below to take photos. Afterwards, stroll the extensive landscaped gardens. The palace and grounds were designed by Peter The Great after a visit to Versailles in France. I guess he didn't want to be outdone. The gardens sit on the edge of the Gulf of Finland providing spectacular views. You can get a ticket to include the palace and grounds, or for the grounds only. Expect to spend most of the day if you plan to do both.

THE most spectacular fountains and gardens we have ever seen!. Wow, first saw the amazing sight of these spectacular fountains and gardens from the air as we were flying in from Helsinki....what a sight....nearly fell out of the plane with excitement! We already had prepurchased our entry tickets and hydrofoil...so was well and truly anticipating the experience.....and it didn't disappoint. The hydrofoil is definitely the way to go and an interesting quick trip up the River Neva. Unfortunately it was raining the day we went, but we had taken raincoats and umbrella with us and a plastic bag just for the camera (the stalls @ Peterhof charge inflated prices for these essential items apparently it rains regularly....hence the availability of water for the fountains). On arrival, there is a short walk up from the pier to the lower gardens.....didn't seem to be much of a queue, but we went straight through with our tickets. Important tip.....the upper gardens don't have an entrance fee but if you leave the lower gardens and go to return from upper to lower, you will need to pay for your tickets again! No pass outs at all, we looked over the barrier at the upper ones and decided the lower ones were much preferable anyway. Another tip.....if you can manage the timing.....get there before 11am so you can get some photos of the fountains before they are switched on and enjoy the classical music and show of the water trickling in and up, then obviously, the photos with all the fountains flowing freely.....spectacular. We chose not to go into the Palace as we were going to Catherine and Pavlovsk Palaces later in the week....wise decision, we ran into another couple who had done this palace too and they said there was a sameness to them....whereas when we went to the other palaces, it was all a fresh new experience. There really aren't enough superlatives to describe this place.....not to be missed...even in the rain!

Beautiful and fun. I have visited in early summer and early fall - gardens are beautiful in both seasons. The trick fountains are fun for people watching. Allow enough time to explore the gardens and see as many fountains as possible (there are well over 100). It's a way from the city - consider getting there by hydrofoil - more expensive but much faster.
Amazingly beautiful. Beautiful. Stunning. Wow. Downsides are no photos inside and rude visitors from the east of Russia who show no courtesy or consideration for fellow visitors.

Breathtaking Fountains and Gardens. During the summer season, Peterhof was somewhat of a mixed bag of goods. Getting there from St. Petersburg was exceptionally easy via the hydrofoil boats that leave regularly from a dock just outside the Winter Palace on the Neva. The boats are quite comfortable and make the trip along the Gulf of Finland in about 45 mins or less. Once off the boat, that's where things get dicey. The ticket kiosks are located in the absolute worst place for the hoards of people coming off the boats from the city. Whomever planned this should be shot. Once you've dealt with that and make your exit from the dock area, you are treated to an impressive view of the palace along the arm of water that connects to the fountains. To either side there are expansive and lovely gardens and parks with tree-lined walking paths and small fountains. Once you get up to the palace itself, you get the full effect of the magnificent golden fountains and the expanse of the palace itself. You really could spend most for your day just taking this all in and enjoying the parks and gardens without ever setting foot inside the palace museum. The queues are huge and entry into the various segments of the palace museum can be confusing. The tour of the interior rooms was lackluster. Our visit was on a warm (though not hot) day in August, and the crowds were oppressive, almost beyond belief and endurance. And there is no AC inside the palace, which all made for an incredibly uncomfortable experience (we couldn't wait to get outside for air). Perhaps off season it is much more manageable as far as the crowds go, but during high season, it is not fun. However, and in spite of the crowds, the fountains alone really are worth the trip, and the parks and gardens and views are simply stunning. It was very sad to see from photographs how badly Peterhof was damaged during the war. A great many things, including palace furnishings and the fountain statues, were taken away at the start of the war to save them, but the palace itself and grounds were virtually destroyed--only the shell of the palace was left standing, so that virtually everything you see has been rebuilt and/or restored. But what an incredible restoration to its former glory it is, and all things considered (which is a lot), it is an amazing sight and worth every effort to get to and see.

Beautiful Fountains and Grounds. On our last visit to St Petersburg we toured the sights in Pushkin, so this visit was Peterhof. We had a private guide to show us around, which was nice, because getting there and finding your way around would be difficult without a plan of Peterhof, which we did not have. The palace is very pretty, kind of a slightly smaller version of Catherine's palace in Pushkin, and the fountains are marvelous. The grounds are expansive, with plenty of other things to see. Even late September with no sun that day, a very worthwhile experience.

Wowww. Since enter it .. it's very huge and beautiful.. i went there on last Tuesday which the palace is close but i still enjoy the atmosphere around .. the fountain and lower park garden also excellent .. take hydrofoil back to hermitage which cost 700 rubles and it's excellent only 30 mins traveling .. love this place alots and will be back

Not Impressed. I think our mistake was seeing the Hermitage Museum on our first day in Russia. Everything else simply pales in comparison. To be fair, they were setting up for a big concert and show at Peterhof the day we were there, and it definitely detracted from the beauty of the place.
Fountains of beauty. The 11 fountains were worth the trip to see, all set to go off at the same time. A thing of beauty of view.The grounds and plantings were also beautiful.

outstanding. we arrived by hydrofoil from st petersburg, seems to be a popular option to get there. we arrived just as the music began and the fountains started, impressive fountain stairway in lower garden, not sure how many fountains there were but all very impressive, this is not just one palace but a whole complex of palaces, plan ahead here, there are some unusual arrangments when getting access to the palaces - not for the faint hearted or those bothered by crowds, timing is key

Peterhof. Took a hydro boat from the Hermitage Museum to Peterhof that took about 20 minutes by water. Many interesting building and shipyards along the way, but Peterhof and its Gardens are a must see.

Best Guides tour of St. Peterhof. We booked a 2 day tour of St Petersburg with Best Guides as Russia has changed their entry requirements and all tourists must now apply for a visa or book a guided tour. We opted for the tour and enjoyed every minute of it. We could never have seen all that we did on our own agenda. Peterhof was my main goal and we travelled there by hydrofoil after a tour of the city. Speeding down the River Neva, which is extraordinarily wide and arriving by water was great. It was remarkable to arrive just in time for the waterfalls to start with the operatic music. Then we did a tour of St. Peter the Great's private cottage which we chose from 3 options. Our guide Elena was a veritable encyclopaedia of facts, information and appreciation of art. We were ushered in to all the museums on an early pass to miss the crowds and crammed as much as possible into the time we spent at each place. After a lovely lunch we went onto Catherine's Palace in Pushkin. The next day was an exhausting day through the Hermitage, Church of the Spilled Blood, a very interesting ride on the metro and visiting the markets and a boat ride on the Neva. There is so much history and places to visit that I feel we need a second visit to truly appreciate this city.

Summer palace gardens . We have just visited peterhof gardens and fountains. Our tour did not include an inside visit to palace, am not sure if it was open inside. The front gardens which included the fountains were very beautiful but I would not recommend going all that way if you could not see inside the palace Saying that we were recommended to go to see the gardens and people were raving about it .

Magnificent palace with gold everywhere. The fountains outside with their gold statuary is unbelievable as are the grounds. It is hard to find words to describe the magnificence of the place. Gold is everywhere. Art is everywhere. A must see.

Lovely place. It's a massive park, too big to take it all in in just one day, but we got a good impression of the lower gardens and its fountains. As with all places in St. Petersburg in summer, it gets crowded quite quickly and the ticket office is not exactly the most efficient in the world, but it's definitely worth a visit.

If you only visit one palce in St Petersburg this is it!!. We had a private guide for this tour and she was excellent booked through Viatours and I would strongly recommend this if you don't read Russian. The place is stunning inside and out, allow 2.5 hours or so to do it justice.

Great gardens, rebuilt palace with massive amounts of 'bling'. We visited as part of group which meant we were, I think, allowed in before it palace opened to the general public. Even with tickets we still had to stand in line to go in and it was still really crowded as we snaked through the rooms. Lots of 'bling' though not quite as OTT as the Catherine Palace.Be aware that what you see is pretty much total rebuild - the palace was left little more than a shell at the end of WWII.Someone mentioned 'the dragons' in each room. I think they were just trying to prevent total gridlock! I found that saying smiling and saying 'good morning' in dreadful Russian almost always resulted in a smile back. Make sure to allow lots of time to explore the grounds with all the fountains.

It makes you dizzy!. Our short visit to St Petersburg left us breathless. This place was as stunning as the others we visited, and like them, very busy with lots of tours snaking their way round in orderly lines. It means you cannot really stop and stare much, but it is a definite 'must see' destination.Another location where you are surrounded by opulence, grandeur, wealth etc. And knowing some of the history brings it very much to life.
X visit to Peterhof; palace of Peter the Great. Over the top magnificence in a beautiful environment. Extremely well maintained. Must be included in any trip to St Petersburg.

The palace with Fountains. This palace was built to have gardens to rival Versailles. The palace itself is not as grand as the Hermitage or Catherine's Palace, but the building sits atop a hill overlooking the Gulf of FinlandThe tour of the gardens or just walking with a guide book can take you hours at Peterhof. Don't miss the checkerboard or the walkway to the gulf. The highlight is the Samson Fountain. Check for times when the fountains are turned on. Samson didn't come on until 11 am when we were there. Inside the palace there is a gift shop, which takes credit cards. Once in the gardens there are carts for food and souvenirs which only take rubles. There is one cafe in the Orangery area that will take credit cards for a snack or meal.Go early to beat the crowds and wait for the fountains to turn on.

Fantastic Estate. When visiting here, think about Peter the Great creating an Estate from nothing and doing it in such a fantastic manner. The multi houses, gardens and fountains are a joy to see and experience. Suggestion: take the hydrofoil from St. Petersburg.
Beautiful gardens an fontains. One of the places to visit when in St. Petersburg.The Palace has a great location next to the sea and the garden/fountain complex worth a visit

Stunning in its grandure. These old Emperors and Tsars really knew how to live it up – and then some. Like Catherine’s palace it was bombed heavily during the WW2 and again beautifully restored to the grandeur that it now is. The gardens, fountains, trees and waterfalls are so dramatic. It was only used during the summer months by the Tsars.

A Must See. I just wish I was a Tsar.. Amazing Architecture. Dramatic Grounds. Beautiful Fountains. And lots and lots of gold. An absolute must see when in St. Petersburg. We took the hydrofoil boat from St Petersburg for a quick 30 to 40 minute ride to Peterhof. Lots of people and large crowds, so arrive early.

Amazing Experience. Take the ferry from near the Hermitage. There are several to choose from so don't take the first price offered. I paid 900 rubels return but some asked for 1300. Plan at least 6 hrs maybe more. There is lots to see several palaces , museums and extensive gardens and numerous fabulous fountains. It's extremely badly organized with a lot of lines for entry tickets. Little to none information in English. Be prepared for the bad and rude manners of staff, unfortunately not uncommon in Russia. Dispite all the negative truly an amazing thing to see. Don't miss it.

Better than Versailles. A massive park with more than 150 fountains (some form large groups), the Grand Palace with a few smaller interesting buildings, canals and artificial lakes must be seen between late in May and end of September when the fountains are working. The sight not to be missed is the daily ceremony of starting the Grand Cascade and the Samson fountain at 11.00. There is sort of an open car trip arouns the park which lasts 40 minutes but the commentary is in Russian only, so I would suggest reading about the sights on their website first. Allow at least 4 hours, but there is enough to do if you want to stay longer. There is a decent restaurant/cafe, though quite pricey.

Touring Peterhof. I went on a tour to visit Peter the Great's palace. I was with a tour group, had a long wait to get inside of the palace, and once everyone was herded inside, we were all taken from room to room, not allowed to take any pictures. We just walked through fairly quickly because there were so many other tour groups waiting to get through. The rooms were beautifully decorated, but I thought Catherine's palace was much nicer, and you were allowed to take pictures there. If I were to do it over again, I would skip the tour of Peter's palace, maybe just take a walk around the gardens which you can do with one of those tours that just takes you around to highlighted areas and stops long enough for everyone to take pictures.

Feast for the eyes. Amazing gardens, fountains and rich interiors. We were part of a tour and you need it for this place or prepare to queue for a real long time. We went straight through the group entrance and could see the individual visitors long queues.Prepare to spend some time to take in all the marvels

Stunning. We couldn't go inside and it was absolutely pouring but still we walked the magnificent gardens which run from the palace to the sea. Steeped in history with magnificent gold fountains and trick fountains, it is a marvel to behold.

It's about the Gardens!. We took a full day tour (9 hours) that included the Peterhof and Catherine's Palace/Pushkin. Between the two, the actual palace at Catherine's Palace was more impressive and bigger than Peterhof. However, the gardens at the Peterhof are just spectacular. I've visited Versailles a number of times and it's to that palace that the Peterhof often is compared. While Versailles' gardens may be bigger, the ones at the Peterhof, in my opinion, were not only better preserved but are just more stunning and grand. The centerpiece of this, without a doubt, is the jaw dropping serious of fountains at the staircase around the palace's back. You may have seen the pictures, but it's all that more incredible in person. I remember when I first saw the Eiffel Tower, I was so taken aback by how much bigger it was than what I imagined it to be; this is the same impression I got when seeing the grand fountains at the Peterhof staircase. I could have easily stood there for an hour and just observed and not be bored for a minute. The gardens also have a manicured French section and a more rambling English section, both with different fountains all around. We walked all the way back to the Monplaisir cottage (which we did not enter), on the Gulf of Finland, and were able to get a distant view of Kronstadt and St. Petersburg itself. We also had lunch at a restaurant nearby, very much in the woods on what appears to be palace grounds but you really have to look for it. It was touristy, definitely geared for tour groups, but it was actually good. By the way, there are two gardens at the Peterhof. The one I've been writing about is the lower garden. Beside the gardens and fountains, there's a large canal that runs from the palace all the way to the Gulf of Finland. Per our tour guide, this was the way to arrive at the Palace if you came by boat. What a welcome!! The upper gardens, while beautiful as well, were at the front entrance when arrival was by coach. Peterhof is definitely a must while in St. Petersburg but if you have limited time, make sure you at least visit the lower gardens (oh, and grand fountains do not function during winter and other cold times of the year so check the schedule). A beautiful tour.

The most impressive palace we saw. Outside the city is the home of Peter the Great and his heirs, the grounds feature 150 fountains, one more amazing than the other. They use gravity to make the flow. The Peterhof sits on the Gulf of Finland and was Peters summer home. It is filled gilded rooms, Chinese cabinets, and wonderful parquet floors. But really the outstanding thing for me was the myriad of fountains that dot the grounds. we hired a private car and guide who was able to get us into the palace before it opened. We were done touring and outside on the grounds before the busses arrived. Well worth the extra money. The fountains are turned off in the late fall..so be careful of your visit dates

Grounds and building very impressive. My wife and I went here on an organised trip with a local tour guide. We were warned before entering of the 'dragons' (we had no idea what they were). We had to queue for nearly one hour to enter the building (the entry used for tour groups), not very nice. Once inside we found who the 'dragons' were, local women in each room insisting the tour guide kept walking, with comments, hand gestures etc., a very rushed tour with being pushed through from one room to another. The grounds are amazing, very impressive

Stunning. From the first moment you enter and go up the ornately decorated stairs, you are led through a series of incredibly decorated rooms, all designed and decorated to eclipse Versailles. When you then go outside to the incredible fountains in the lower garden you think that maybe Peter the Great and his later successor, Catherine, succeeded.

Excellent place to visit. We enjoyed our visit to Peterhof very much. We purchased our tickets online before arriving. We took the Hydrofoil boat to get there. It was pleasant and well worth the visit!
Beautiful.. A gem. Very nice historical place. Good location, not far from St Petersburg. Breathtaking views. Very popular, so sometimes overcrowded.

Best fountains and park. Museum was closed day of our visit. Enormous crowds fill this site. Bath house was interesting. Fountains and grounds truly fit for a Czar. Peter's 7 room house good scale and magnificent. Go early!

Amazing National treasure. The fountains are truely amazing. Gold, gold everywhere! On a nice day the gardens are very good for a wander. Peter the Great's small house near the water is very special and not to be missed if you follow this great leader.
Enchanting. Great experience. We travel by hydrofoil one way, back by metro. Challenging way back if you don't know the language , but worth the experience

Absolutely amazing.........Fit for a Tsar, a King, a Queen and an Emperor.. This is a must for anyone visiting St. Petersburg as it gives you a feel for the countryside and then palatial grandeur of Tzarist times. The Peterhof Palace is on the banks of the Bay of Finland and hides in the forest until you are adjacent to it when all its spledour is revealed. TRAVEL TIP - visit it by coach on the outward journey and return via the Peterhof Express hydrofoil for a journey to remember up the Neva River to the Palace Square. Inside the Palace, is a maze of beautiful gold gilt rooms in honour of Peter and Catherine. There is a set tour which speeds you through at haste !!! You will be expected to hand in rucksacks, outdoor coats, umbrellas and made to wear overslips on your shoes to preserve the parquee flooring. The manicured gardens are a joy to behold with paths, fountains, water features and a central canal that leads to the hydrofoil pier.....a motor train is available if you do not to walk. TOP TIP...the main cascade fountains do not get switched on until 11.00am so get there by 10.45 to get a great view. Peterhof Palace is a very popular place to visit with thousands of visitors daily but it is so well appointed that at times you can feel as if you are there on your own. Facinating.

You could spend the whole day. Peterhof is an amazing place - fit for a Tsar! It is a campus of palaces, museums, secondary buildings, gardens, walks, fountains and more, located about an hour outside of central Saint Petersburg. The gardens are much more formal than those at Catherine's Palace and they are populated by fountains of two basic types - regular decorative fountains of the kind with which we are all familiar (although these are on a grand scale) and "trick" fountains which do not appear to be fountains but are designed to catch the guest unawares and soak him (such as when you approach a particular bench in a glade). Peter the Great must have had an interesting sense of humor. The grounds are extensive and beautiful. We did not do the main palace but did the grounds and gardens, the bath block (with an amazing shower) and the Hermitage (with an ascending and descending table - worth a visit) and that took us three hours. Each palace or attraction is priced separately; there does not appear to be a "all-included combination ticket." The Museum's website (in both Russian and English) gives detailed information on the nature and price of each palace or attraction.
A MUST PLACE TO VISIT. Very remarkable place to visit. One of the most beautiful and impressive places you will visit in the world. It really make you think about the wealth of the Russian Tsars.
Scenic and tranquil. The gardens and museum worth while a visit.So much glamour but the atmosphere/surrounds relaxing.The building itself picturesque

Beautiful. Pererhof offers stunning views of gardens and fountains as well as the beautiful summer palace. Make sure you go on a nice day. The trip would not be worth it if the weather does not cooperate. Bring comfortable shoes.

Excelent place. The museum is very good preserve, we saw tons of interesting pieces and art works in all the place, we suggested to take a guide tour in your language with few people in order you to enjoyed it

Impressive!. After touring Peterhof, I was pleasantly surprised when we emerged into a beautiful garden filled with gilded statues and lively fountains. They immediately reminded me of Versailles, which I had visited years ago. We arrived early in the morning, however by 10:00 AM the crowds were definitely growing and it was difficult to get in close to the fountains, which go off at 11:00 AM. Venture out beyond the main stairway and you will be treated with a number of smaller gardens and fountains. I'd recommend at least 2 hours to explore the grounds and watch the fountains.

Beautiful Castle like Versailles. Peterhof is the summer castle of Peter the Great. Although on the outskirts of St. Petersburg, about 45min outside the city, it is a beautiful destination. You will need to put booties over your shoes to preserve the flooring and you will need to check your raincoats/umbrellas etc... as the doorways are super tiny. The Gardens outside are the best part.

A Grand Palace with even Grander Fountains. This is a "must see" palace in St. Petersburg. Built some three centuries ago, fully renovated (to original design), the palace is spacious, functional and opulent. The flooring design and matching ceiling design are intricate. The gardens are one of the best in Europe. The fountains, designed to be gravity fed, are a spectacle which should not be missed.

beautiful garden and water fountains - not to be missed. it is a crowded place and we were rushed through the garden and fountains. The beauty of the garden is unbelievable. we have never seen a garden like this in massive scale anywhere else.......

Peterhof is not to be missed!. I had a day on my own in St. Petersburg, and decided to take the hydrofoil from Admiralty Docks out to Peterhof. It was a great way to spend the day. The hydrofoil takes about 35 minutes to get there, after which you pay to enter the gardens. A second line and admission fee gets your into the Peterhof Palace. The grounds are stunning and the palace rivals Versailles in its opulence. I did this without a guide, and probably would have learned more about the palace with a guided tour, but each room has signs that explain the history and architecture / design. I left Admiralty at 10am and got back around 3:30pm, so it was a nice part-day excursion.

spectacular garden, rushed tour. Went here on Monday when only tour groups are allowed in the main building. Between the silver seas cruise and the numerous chinese tour groups, the building was packed. Sadly, the way this is set up is intended to move everyone along quickly in order to get everyone through the building. No photos as that will slow you down, no lingering in rooms between the main attractions as that will slow you down, etc. Hence, the interior was not as enjoyable as I would have liked. Having said this, despite a rainy day, the gardens, especially the fountains, are magnificent and you have as much time there as you like. Get outside by 11am and you can see the turning on of the fountains. The grand cascade is spectacular and the trick fountains are fun. If you like the Versailles Gardens, you'll love these.

Worth a visit but take the circular route. It is amazing to visit Peterhof and its splendid gardens but be warned there are many, many tourists (often local and oftener Chinese), everything is exclusively in Russian and they push the packs through the rooms pretty quickly to avoid major queues. I DO recommend the minibus from Avtovo, go down through the upper garden to the palace then after the visit keep going down to return by hydrofoil. It's cheaper, just as quick and you see some things you would otherwise miss.

Great palace, great art, fanciful gardens. Peter's creative imagination went wild in his mansion and his gardens. This place is Versailles on Russian steroids. Gold everywhere, frescoes, baroque moldings, sculptures, art pieces and a classical garden with various fountains, paths and royal forests. Visiting here will make you happy!
Stunningly beautiful. Highly recommend. Beautiful palace , crowds well managed, beautful grounds. A mustsee attraction. Come after 2pm to avoid the larg tour groups

Peterhof, St. Petersburg. We visited the grounds and the Treasury. The fountains and buildings look amazing from outside (we didnt go in) and the way leading up to the main entrance was very impressive with fountains etc.The gounds were extensive but we found it rather stylised as everything - trees, paths, grasses, fountains were all arranged neatly and in a geometric pattern. The many fountains in the grounds were interesting though. Not many flowers and quite different from British -type gardens. We went into the Treasury which was not cheap but found it really disappointing for the price we had to pay! The exhibits were very limited and not impressive at all. It took us only a very short while to see them all!

The Phoenix of Tzarist opulence.. So many WOW!s at Peterhof State Museum Preserve that one doesn't know where to start! Research a little of the palace before you go to see the damage done by Nazi occupation. To imagine that the current buildings and gardens were dragged back from that almost total destruction is absolutely awesome. The opulence drips both inside and out. I concentrated on the Palace as I was on a tour - my son and his family toured the gardens a couple of days later and we compared notes. It would seem to me to be worth taking extra time and doing both! I do feel I missed out on the gardens. TripAdvisor has so many photos as well as there being umpteen books available that I would also recommend you save time and photograph only where you are including people or something you see that is particularly quirky. Unless you are a keen photographer you will probably be satisfied with the plethora of images of the Palace and Gardens which are on line. Another thing you could do to save a little time is to avoid the cafes at the end of the canal. They clearly don't care for repeat business and I'd say it's just as well as I'd never eat there again! 3rd rate food, surly staff and crazy prices. But do go! It is truly wonderful!
Part of 2 Day TJTravel tour. Very interesting and expansive. Lots of walking and want to do on a non rainy day. Give your self plenty of time.

Opulence inside and out. The Russians have made it a mission to make sure their history is preserved and they have done it beautifully. This museum and the fabulous gardens reflect in ever detail a different time and culture. The restoration has been impeccable and complete. Some of the before and after pictures were the most interesting to me as one can see the massive project the restoration took. We could have spent another day here and thoroughly enjoyed it but we just ran out of time.

Beautiful gardens. We did not go into the palace, but spent our time outside in the gardens. You can take a hydrofoil to and from which is fast. I would not think you'd need a guide if you have a good guide book. The grounds seem endless and ever changing. They are well maintained, and lovely. It is crowded in the summer so go with that expectation.

Peterhof State Museum Preserve. This is the Versailles of Russia. 250 acres of gardens and out buildings each with it's own historical purpose. The gardens are not just grand, but restful. The fountains and sculptures are not just pretty, but well designed and restorative to human nature. The shore side location is beauty beyond belief. The opulence inside is to be expected of that era: grand rooms, grand furnishings, gold leaf, beautiful hand laid wooden floor mosaics. Don't miss any of it! If possible, walk with your hands in your own pockets! Best way to thwart pickpockets! If you don't have a personal guide, get the audio guide, but be aware of your surroundings!
Peterhof . Peterhof is very beautiful. Especially with good weather. But it is also very expensive. We had to pay for every museum extra and the staff at Peterhof is not very friendly.

Another wonderful palace and gardens. Gorgeous sunny day with strong cool breeze. Took hydrofoil across. Strolled around the gardens and fountains. The breeze dissipated and it was very busy but pleasant. Many families with young children enjoying the sun and the gardens. The palace - well it was certainly a palace! Absolutely gorgeous! Easy trip back by car. Definitely worth a visit.
Stunning. If you are reading this it is likely because you are thinking about visiting St. Petersburg. This place is stunning. Don't read about it.Go and see it. Life is short.

Best summer palace. Unique place with beautiful gardens and parks, unique fountains, don't miss short ride at golf car through all park - easy and fast way to look. Also visit oranienbaum- Menshikov's palaces- just opened after renovation

Stunning!. This is a must see. The architecture, the art, the grounds....all were impressive. Not quite as well maintained as Versailles, but in that range. It definitely makes my list of top 10 Castles.
Fantastic. Arrive by boat if you can, the gardens are spectacular. So many fountains all gravity fed, So much to see, so little time to do it justice.

Words + loads of pics not enough. SPB Tours guide Luba managed to steer us round these fabulous gardens, whilst somehow avoiding most of the huge crowds, - though we did experience these for the 11am fountain show. Still worth it though! Great fun trying to throw coins (kindly supplied by Luba) into the boots of a very high statue (apparently very lucky if you manage it). Loved the 'trick' fountains too ... very sneaky! Definitely a must see if you are visiting St Petersburg - and if you can manage to secure the services of Luba you will be even more delighted!
Very beautiful but crowded. It's beautiful and amazing place. But the entrance charge is not fair enough.it's crowded too much and border you to taking photos.

Stunning!. We took the hydroboat- best way to get there. Like most places in St. pete, both the boat and the museum have student discounts (even international students) so it's a great help. The boat ride is enjoyable. The museum itself is gorgeous but the best, in my opinion, are the gardens, the fountains, and everything outside. It's fun to find the hidden fountains and get unexpectedly wet!

Stunning Palace and gardens. On a recent visit to St Petersburg on our cruise ship, we were on an organised tour of the Peterhof Palace and its extensive grounds. As expected, the palace was incredibly large and stunning. The wealth of the former Russian Czar regimes were on show for all to see. We ventured through the extensive gardens and fountain areas to the lake, and were on site for the 11.00 am display at the main fountain area adjoining the palace.This attraction is hugely popular with many thousands of people visiting from cruise ships and the like. You need to put up with huge crowds, but it is a must see if you are visiting St Petersburg.

Amazing Museum. So many items to see , you need a guide to help to get the best out of the visit. It's a place you can spend a day looking at the exhibits . Also one could learn the the history of Russia had connections with other Europian countries .

Beautiful Palace and Grounds. We visited Peterhof as part of our Viking River Cruise from Moscow to St Petersburg. The exterior as well as interior has been restored from the ravages of WWII. The rooms are in succession from gilded to silk walls. The grounds run up to the Baltic Sea and contains beautiful landscaping and fountains. A must see!

The park is great, the palace is un-organized. The parks are perfect and beautiful.The palace has absolute mess on entrance and exit - terrible unorganized queues for the wardrobe, terrible in rainy day, when you have to keep your rain-coats in one cloak-room, the umbrellas in another. Same mess on exit, when you have to collect all your belongings and the same time with hundreds of China tourists.So the positive feeling from the palace is totally ruined by the mess.

Tour of Peterhof through NCL. Overall nice tour if you like history and visiting palaces. The only thing we didn't like about the tour was that they shoved people into the palace and there was no semblance of crowd control, so keep small children close to you.

Tour Set up by Oceania Cruises. Peter the Great had a seaside retreat that was originally very understated until his daughter Elizabeth became queen. Then it grew into this amazing series of buildings and gardens that will take you at least four 4 hours to see just the highlights. Go with a guide.

All I can say is "WOW". What a great place to visit. We only toured the outside gardens and fountains. The area around the stairs was PACKED! Once you get away from all the people, you can really take in the beauty of this place. It is Central Park plus Versailles on steroids. It is absolutely stunning.

Fountains!. If you like fountains this is the palace/grounds for you. The parkland is also quite extensive and it's hard to see it all in one visit. A pleasant trip on the hydrofoil has you there in 30 minutes from the Admiralty building on the Neva. I found it more enchanting than Versailles, after which the Peterhof is modeled.

Sumptuous palace, poor organisation, disappointing gardens. The palace is what you would expect of its era, sumptuous rooms, beautiful furniture, furnishings and all the decoration to match. On the downside there was a long queue to get into the palace (after acquiring tickets at the entrance) and the visit itself was rushed. First you go to a cloakroom to deposit coats, then a second to deposit bags, then you line up again to get shoe covers. The tour (we were with an experienced guide) was rushed - we were told by the guide that she had had complaint made by the Peterhof to her employer for talking too slowly on her previous visit. At the end of the tour we had again to queue up twice at the cloakrooms and, as there is no exit beyond the cloakrooms, double back and edge through crowds coming through the cloakrooms to exit. The gardens were very disappointing, There are a lot of fountains and gilded statutory near to the palace and other fountains throughout what was more managed light woodland than gardens, I expected gardens similar to the Hapsburg palaces or even French chateau but the gardens here are nothing like those.

Another stunning palace. The tour we had of this palace was guided although you can do it on your own. The palace is stunning inside and out and although partially destroyed during the WW2 it has been faithfully restored and hard to see where unless pointed out to you. No photos allowed inside because of inconsiderate tourists from one particular country taking too many and holding other tours up. No problems outside in the grounds taking photos and there are plenty of photo opportunities from the palace to the many beautiful fountains and shaded walkways. Be aware that pickpockets operate here and lay traps for the unsuspecting tourists. I myself was nearly caught out, having spotted a Hundred dollar bill lying on the grass I picked it up in one fluid movement and moved on quickly only to discover it was a poor fake. Do not let this put you off, just take precautions and you will have a great time
We arrive by a short and exciting batiscafo navigation. Julia, our guide, was an d a excellent person and a very wise guide to select the most important things in the time available for the tour

Beautiful as everyone says. We engaged a private guide for a tour. He helped navigate the queues quickly. No photos inside, but still worth the visit. The grounds are amazing. **The grounds & fountains are open on the day the museum is closed. It may be an opportunity to see them without thousands of tourists straining to see the Grand Cascade - will try that next time.

Wow!. About 40mins outside St Petersburg on a hydrofoil. Stunning gardens and fountains! Go with a guide to make sure you arrive to see the fountains switched on. The loo queues were terrible.... be warned!!This is a "must see" place.

Beautiful Palace!. We took the hydrofoil to the Palace on an SPB tour. The ride over took about 30 to 40 minutes. When you arrive, there is a good walk up to the palace, but as you approach you begin to see the beauty that awaits. The Palace is covered with gold and surrounded by beautiful gardens and fountains covered with gold. We did not go inside, but enjoyed the very beautiful grounds and gardens for about an hour. It is beautiful!
Beautiful!. Amazing gardens and many fountains. We visited the summer Place and walked all over the grounds. We saw the fountains starting at 1100. Not to be missed on your SPB trip!

Very impressive palace with lots of history. Very well coordinated place with really interesting historical talking points - photos of what the Germans did to the place during WWII and the resurrection over many decade. Opulent and amazing palace and grounds.

Versailles, Sanssouci... and Peterhof!. Take the boat Metropol in St Petersburg (near the Ermitage) that runs from 10 am to 6pm. Be aware that they don't really speak English (and are not friendly either!) and you have to decide the time of your return: I took the boat at 10.20am and was so surprised by the "you must decide now" that I said "5pm". Which turned out to be fine; 4pm would have been good as well. The visit of the Palace itself is super quick since they process groups so you don't really have time to enjoy the rooms. Then more time for the gardens. Be aware that you have to pay for everything separate: the park fee is paid upon your arrival at the pier; the palace is paid inside. And then all pavillons (Marly, Monplaisir) are also separately paid. It's difficult if you are not part of a group or not Russian speaking since the times are not clearly stated. But this is a must! Probably the best I have seen in my Russian trip! Be lucky enough to have a sunny day since it is still windy (yes, up North!)

Get there before the crowds!. We had a tour guide, which allowed us to gain entry before the masses. This is a must at many tourist destinations. We were able to enjoy the museum, the palace, and the palace grounds all without crowds. There were a couple of other tour groups that we bumped into from time to time but nothing that was inconvenient. Of course, the fountains don't start until late morning so we did need to compete for good viewing space at that time, but after a few minutes of viewing, we were well satisfied and were able to leave without any trouble.

Amazing layout & the many fountains. Known as the Russain Versilles,bathe ornate palace overlooks the Gulf of Finland. The Grand Cascade fountain features Samson prying open a loin's jaw as water cascades down the terraced steps. What a wonderful site it is... The fountains are operated manually with the air pressure system. If you move around the outside area, one can discover other smaller fountains & falls as well... There is a huge cafe outside for refreshments as well.

Beautiful fountains. We didn't go in to see the palace but we did view the fountains. They were all different and many many of them but be prepared to do alot of walking. The fountains are quite spread apart.

Wow!. The fountains started at 11am. It was such a beautiful show with water spouting up and music playing in the background. We really enjoyed the private tour explaining the mechanics of the fountains and where the water came from. We also enjoyed walking the grounds and seeing Peter the Greats summer cottage.
Dazzling. To walk in Peter the Great's back yard was thrilling. Gardens, fountains and the view of The Baltic as Peter the Great saw it was such a memorable moment in our visit... Rain or shine!

A must visit palace. A beautiful reconstructed palace and gardens. Such opulence is overwhelming and beautiful. We were taken round by an English speaking guide so we're told details about this venue.

Beautiful grounds, despite the huge crowds. The crowds are oppressive during the short summer tourist season. Cruise ships and Russians combine to make it wall to wall people inside the main building. Even outside on the balconies and cascading water fountain areas, it was slammed with people. Yes there are moments when you get a break from the hordes of people and catch a beautiful view, which make you glad that you visited it. Inside the tour guides and employees allow you maybe 30 seconds per room as they are bent on pushing as many people through there as they can. Most of the details have been stripped from the building and there is very little original about it. "Versailles of the Baltics"? Not even close.I don't mean to sound overly negative, as compared to the rest that St. Petersburg has to offer it is worth the visit. We did catch a sunny day, would have hated it in the rain.

Fabulous, breathtaking palace. The interior is quite extraordinary - lots of gold and gilt and to use a modern expression 'bling'. Do go early, we arrived at 9.00 when it opened for groups so had a painless trip around. However when we came out there were huge queues! The gravity fed fountains are quite spectacular, but expect to find yourself fighting for a vantage point. The first bridge gives a good view of the fountains but is much sort after and the selfie sticks rise like a forest to interfere with the view of anyone at the back of the throng. Wandering around the park is worthwhile.

Fountains Are Not to Be Missed. Peter the Great created this palace with the aim of impressing people with the fountains. You WILL be impressed. They are splendid and varied. We also very much enjoyed Peter's small "palace" at the end of the long walkway, just on the Gulf of Finland. Lovely.

A Must See!. This was our second time to Peterhof and we can never get enough. The grounds and gardens are amazing and the Palace is incredible. Should we make it back a third time, this will be the first stop once again.

Spectacular gardens. Words cannot express how beautiful the gardens were. The fountains were magnificent, the flowers, and trees and vistas were candy to my eyes! I wish we had had more time to spend in the gardens. We were on a tour, so we had only a limited amount of time to spend. Well worth the visit, if you have time, plan to spend the day.

The Best Thing we did in St. Petersburg. Hire a guide through your hotel, a day's notice worked for us. The trip via hydrofoil is worth the time savings and WOW factor for the teens. We didn't feel rushed through the palace as others mentioned. Perhaps due to the private guide? Nadia was amazing and we had special access to the amazing grotto to see the innovative water/fountain system that Peter installed on the grounds. The teens enjoyed learning about the saved art and statues from the Nazis during WWII from the guide. Well worth the trip! Save time for ice cream before returning to St. Petersburg. Just sit back in the park and enjoy the people watching. Don't MISS THIS!
Super Son's Place. Built for Catherine's son, it is another great see. The interior and the grounds are well kept and interesting, as is the story of Peter.

Great surroundings, worth a visit. This is one of the things to see in st petersburg.The palace is beautiful, with the art pieces still being the originals, although the rooms themselves have been rebuilt.Entering the palacecis a bit of a drag as 'foreigners ' are seperated from the russians, without any signs in another language than Russian. So it takes a while before you know where to get yor tickets and when you can enter the building. The surrounding grounds are fantastic with very special fountains. A must see, if you can find the time. (half hour boat trip from st petersburg)

Anything for a Czar. Cool hydrofoil boat over to Peterhof and the grounds are spectacular. We were there for the 11 am fountains and that was spectacular. We walked around the grounds for about an hour and didn't go into the house. I think after 3 weeks of touring palaces and such I was done. Plus the sky was about to open up and we wanted to head back to St. Petersburg.

Amazing Gardens. When I recently toured the gardens of Peterhof I was impressed with the formal royal gardens. The garden is amazing with statues, flowerbeds, and of course the amazing fountains. definitely one of the most scenic spots in St, Petersberg area

Amazing!. Peterhof was amazing. Very crowded but amazing. Although we did not see the interior the fountains & gardens were beautiful. I was had had more time but on a tour you have to move. Beware of pick pockets the crowds are a bit pushy & it is easy to become complacent.

Opulence of Peter the Great . Amazing to see the Russian equivalent of Versailles. The gold roofs and gold statues are omnipresent. The system of. Fountains is pretty much original. The grounds and woods are lush and groomed.

Fabulous park & gardens. We didn't have the best weather when we visited - it was dry but overcast. I can't help thinking that everything would have looked even more magnificent had the sun been shining. The main feature of the gardens are the large number of fountains in the area between the Palace and the Gulf of Finland. The view from the coast back to the palace is obscured by woodland so you just get glimpses of the palace but you can see the original building, on a much more modest scale, right on the edge of the sea. This is definitely a must-see on a visit to St Petersburg.

Beautiful Park. We have visited the park on our own (not with a guided tour) and it happened to be the right decision. We bought a hydrofoil roundtrip ticket (1400 Rubal pp) and took the earliest boat at 9am, before it becomes crowded. Took it from right across of the Hermitage, for getting back later for other attractions.As you get to Peterhof, buy a full garden tour ticket. Then go right away to the box office in the palace, before the lines become amazingly long, and buy a scheduled ticket to the palace itself.Since we were on our own, we could take the time and see any statue and all ! The amazing fountains in that huge garden. The guided tours only got to see few of them and skipped many others. You can comfotably take your scheduled tour in the palace and see the rest of the garden. Allow for 4-5 hours for the palace and garden, and 40 minutes for the hydrofoil boat each way.
Don't miss this. Gorgeous grounds & palace... WOW (and take the hydrofoil from downtown one way... and the subway the other. A fabulous day)

Garden to beat all gardens. The palace is amazing but the gardens are up with any in Europe. For anyone who appreciates gardens this is a must. Drove there an took the hydrofoil back to town. Wonderful morning.

One of the best sites.. It was crowded, but worth it. This is what I imagined palaces to be. The décor inside was awesome, but the grounds, gardens, fountains were indescribably wonderful. There are other European palaces you could skip, but not this one. When we left, we boarded an airfoil for the return to the city. Loved it.

Spectacular grounds and waterworks. On a good weather day Peterhof is a truly spectacular venue to observe Russian opulence at its best. From the terrace atop the hill by palace one sees what happens when combines vision with virtually unlimited resources. Looking down at the myriad of pools, pathways and gilded statues interspersed with whimsical fountains it's amazing what Peter the Great created. This site is truly best viewed on a good weather day. If you are not on a tour the best way to get from St Petersburg to Peterhof is by the hydrofoil/ ferry. It runs frequently an is less than half the time by road.

The French fountains of the Peterhof. Peter the Great built this palace copying Versailles. It has over 150 fountains, small waterfalls and reflecting pools. The palace and the large surrounding park are set on the Gulf of Finland close to St. Petersburg. Even in marginal weather it is truly spectacular. Tips: Weather is changeable, so take an umbrella. Wear good walking shoes.. Finally, carry a brown-bag lunch. Nearby is a side street with reasonable souveniers.

Beautiful Palace. This was our 3rd palace in 2 days, which was a little too much. It was of course magnificent, but after a while all of the gold gilding begins to look the same. They do have magnificent fountains and gardens. You can take a hydrofoil back to St. Petersburg from the palace, which was fun.

Magnificent gardens. We visited the gardens as part of a two day tour with DenRus. It was a real highlight of the trip. The fountains were magnificent and we were there for the when the additional fountains were switched on which was great. If the weather is good, this is also a great place for children of all ages. There are fountains that they can play in, especially when the additional ones are switched on. It is worth taking a towel and change of clothes.

very beautiful complex. after the winter palace and the hermitage museum complex in the city itself,this complex of summer palace and gardens are the next best attraction in whole of st.petersburg.the palace itself is beautiful,along with the church. but the highlight is the outdoor gardens and fountains.it is just superb.only it is too crowded at the building area.but the gardens upto the pier is huse and so attractive.one can easily spend a peaceful day with packed lunch.very good for families and kids.the fountains with golden statues,particularly the hercules at the centre, is really good.the greenery of the forest like gardens with immaculately laid pathways is very calming to walk around.a must see in st. petersburg, even though at about 30 kms outside the city centre.

Fantastic gardens . Petergof is a must see when visiting St. Petersburg. IMHO, this place possesses the most beautiful gardens in the world compared to Europe and America. Peter and his descendants definitely had outdone everybody, again!

Amazing Gardens. Wear comfortable shoes! Watch your belongings!We were in time for the water fountain display, what a wonderful sight! The gardens are filled with fountains, some of them are fun for children to play in, others filled with golden statues, all of them great. We went there by boat on a beautiful sunny day with thousands of other tourists. Our driver picked us up at the upper gardens which is a good idea. We wer ready for lunch. Our excellent tour guide Irina from TJ Travel took us to a quiet restaurant for beef Stroganoff, salad and lots of fluids.

Worth seeing. First of all, I have discovered touring Russia that there are a TON of scam artists out there. You want a ticket to go somewhere, and they will buy the ticket, then sell it to you for 10x more than if you just went and got it yourself. Also, they will tell you places are open ONLY when they have a tour guide available to take you, not the actual hours of museums. Do your own research. The fountain at Peterhof is one of the nicest, if not the nicest that I have ever seen in my life. Gold everywhere, and just HUGE! The grounds are really nice to walk around when the weather is good. The museum itself shows incredible grandness, like I witnessed at the Palace of Versailles in Paris. The museum is over the top on security though, to the point of making the experience annoying. Every single room has motion sensors that are going off constantly if somebody gets to close to a rope, etc. There were two kind of crazy old ladies that made it their mission to not let anybody stop in their room. They would approach you and say, "Very valuable! Do not stop! Walk slowly, without stopping, and see very quickly." There was nobody behind my brother and I so we paused a second to look at items in the room, they would come up and say, "No! Do not stop! Keep walking!" I was like, "We paid money to come across the world to here, nobody is being help up here, leave us alone." The rest of our trip, at any other places (and none of them had crazies like that working) we would joke whenever the other stopped walking. "Don't stop! Keep walking! Very valuable." It is like the Spinal Tap movie, "Don't even look at it! You might scratch it!" Anyways, we took bus 404 from in front of Baltiskiy Metro Station to go there. Coming back, you can get on any bus and it takes you back to the metro. I think it was 70 rubles to go, but for some reason we paid double coming back. Not sure why...

Beautiful Palace nearly matching Versaille. What a great place to visit and see how the wealthy rulers lived in the early days of Russian rule. Quite beautiful and much to see. Travel is restricted and must be done on organized tour and most staff have a hard time finding a smile. Found that through most of the Russian museums. Staff is very rigid.....unless dancing at dinner and making tips.
Impressive architecture with beautiful garden. Very nice building with impressive architecture and beautiful garden. Take your time to stroll the ground and look over water.

Another case of dangerous over-crowding. I would not have missed this, as the gardens are well up there with Versailles. But how the over crowding (which seems linked with the horrors of officious gallery attendants) impacted on safety, let alone enjoyment. Once again, huge parties from cruise ships posed problems, some even trying to jump the line for entry to the house (hey guys, I'm a Brit and they didn't get away with it). They also saw fit to annexe the lavatory facilities and God help anyone who was dying to "go". There were insufficient facilities for the numbers using them.The absolute glory of Peterhof is the gardens and they are a photographer's paradise. Even my holiday snaps look good. However, there was some bizarre and downright dangerous behaviour from some visitors. Is it really necessary to climb IN the fountains for your damned selfie? Is it polite to manhandle other people out of the way so you can have your picture taken (for a fee) with some twerp in 18th century costume? Will people really think you time travelled, as well as visiting Russia? So do go, if you get the chance but bear in mind the down sides.

The gardens are the highlight of the estate!. Even if you are going in the warmer months, bring some warm layers, because the wind whips off the water. Peter the Great definitely had a thing for fountains and gardens, and this is where you should spend the bulk of your time. Take some food to sit on the bench and people-watch!

Just do the gardens. This was part of an endless run of st Petersburg tourist sites we did in two days. The trip was tiring and really, how many palaces can you see? We went on our tour from princess and took a private guide who was amazing ( Tatiana from Russian Adventures) and she recommended that we do is one and only see the grounds, a fantastic decision. This was a break in our busy schedule and it was beautiful and relaxing time. The gardens have many areas and styles, wasn't too busy and I could have spent a day here. There was no need to see the palace and this presented a fantastic option.

Out of this World. What a fantastic attraction. A truly wonderful walk up from the hydrofoil pier on a sunny day. The museum is impressive from first sight and just gets better the closer you get. The entire founds are dotted with statues and sculptors. Lots of trees and water features and a unique play area for kids where sprays are activated when walking a certain path.There is just so much to see and the Gold and white buildings, water fountains, gardens and views are fantastic.The view from the front of the museum down over the fountain and don to the entrance at the hydrofoil is breathtaking.Do not miss this attraction but be careful of pickpockets when taking photos.
Extravagance defined. Wonderful gardens which have been designed to highlight the array of eclectic fountains designed by and for Peter the Great. Note a summer destination.
Russian Versailles. Great park with unique water features. Modeled after Versailles in Paris this park is its equal. Be careful some of the water features are sneaky.
Impressive . Peterhof is a great place to visit, but you have to go on a nice day only. There are several fountains and walking paths. Note the times the fountains work.

Awesome!. There is no photography inside. However, it is made up for by the outside gardens which are amazing. The inside is not to be believed it is most gold plated in every room. Leaves you breathless with you mouth open. Very well maintained. The only drawback was that if you spent too much time in one room they would make you move along to the next room. Worth the trip and entrance fee. There are multiple entrance fees to different areas, so make sure what you are paying your money for.
You can do without :). Interesting tour, but long line waiting, not sure they have tours in English. We took garden driving tour - it was nice.

Impressive. An amazing place to visit, both Palace and gardens. We travelled by hydrofoil which was easy, quick and convenient. Make sure you allow plenty time for your visit: you need a full day as you need to queue for tickets and there is a lot to see. The visit to the Palace was guided tours only which were in Russian but we were allowed to wander through on our own which we preferred and there were information signs in English in all the rooms.

Not too much original - most has been restored since WWII. We spent a half day here and had mixed emotions after touring many places within the city of St. Petersburg. Peterhof is about an hours drive from central St. Petersburg. We thought the palace was impressive but there is not a lot that is original as most of it was blown up in WWII. The gardens were impressive, but they were super crowded. People were lined up to see the fountains turn on for more than an hour before they started. It was very packed. On the tour inside, we had to wear slip cover booties over shoes which were very slippery and made a few in our group fall. We're not quite sure why as most of the floors inside the palace were filthy and not yet restored. Maybe it was to protect us. Another issue for me that was not acceptable was that there was absolutely no photography allowed inside. The rooms were very warm inside (we did not find AC anywhere for that matter) and we were tired. Lastly, we’re not sure why, but no one that worked there smiled or was cordial. There were docent's on every corner of every room. It did not seem like a happy place. We hope you like it better than we did.

Probably the most beautiful place in St Peterburg. Went there on a cold, rainy afternoon. It was still awe inspiring. I can only imagine what it would be like on a sunny day with all that gold and colors. The walks and the statues were worth it, even with the weather.

Fountains and gardens. This was a cruise tour. Everything was very beautiful and restored so very well. Such a lot of people though, so it was difficult to really see everything properly. One really needs to spend a whole day here and we only had about 3 hours

lower garden at Peterhof was fantastic. Visited Peterhof on a recent trip to Saint Petersburg, and despite a drizzle and overcast skies we were amazed at how beautiful the lower gardens were. Fountains, statues, flowers, beautifully maintained shrubbery, etc, etc, it was the whole package. The view down one of the canals to the Gulf of Finland only added to the attractiveness of this place.

Another St. Petersburg Experience!. Visited Peterhof Preserve on our 2 day port visit to St. Petersburg. From town, took a motoscafi out to the Preserve. The building itself was still being restored so we were not able to go inside, even with our tour guide from SPB tours. I can imagine what the interior will look like when completely restored.Walked the extensive grounds and gardens and took in all of the fountains.Find out ahead of time if you can get into the Museum. If not, and you don't like extensive walking for a prolonged period of time, I would recommend skipping it until the museum reopens. Too many other beautiful museums and churches to visit in St. Petersburg proper to spend this amount of time going out and coming back on the speed boat just to walk the grounds. Just my opinion.

Beautiful gardens and fountains!. We visited just to see the gardens and fountains which were certainly beautiful and worth a visit. It was raining when we went but still enjoyed strolling through the gardens. Look out for the trick fountains :) Our children (9, 12 & 13) also enjoyed it and playing around in some of the fountains.

Cruise shore visit. Wow what a place, very impressive and a must visit when in St Petersburg Russia
This was a shore visit whilst cruising and was well worth the expense.
The tour itself was made with Alla Tours much cheaper than the boat and hassle free for the visa system.

Amazing refurbishment of a palace destroyed by the Germans. The amount of incredible restoration of the gold in the rooms and the fountains and gardens of the Palace are absolutely beautiful and amazing. There are golden statues all the way down a huge fountain with marble stairs either side which proceeds onto gardens which are manicured perfectly, Over the top beautiful and precious

Beautiful gardens and fountains. Unbelievably beautiful gardens and fountains, superior to Versailles. Even if you don't visit the palace, it is still worth strolling around the grounds, it was a great way to spend a summer's day. Strongly recommend bringing some food with you, food choices are limited and uninspiring.In relation to getting to Peterhof from St Petersburg, there are a number of hydrofoil operators. If it's a long wait between hydrofoils, it may be worth trying a different wharf with a different operator.
Best fountains you will ever see. Beautiful park with the most amazing fountains you will ever see. I visited the small house which is beautifully set out in French Empire fashion

Gardens and fountains alone are worth a visit. We visited only the gardens and fountains at Peterhof as we had seen various other impressive palaces in St Petersburg and decided that an unstructured, outdoor experience was what we needed. We were part of a tour group though we wandered the grounds of Peterhof independently and found this to be ideal. The fountains are numerous and impressive (and of course gilded) and the terraced gardens are lovely - especially with the backdrop of the stunning palace itself. It's a great spot for a picnic lunch and I advise packing one to bring. Be aware that Peterhof is a long drive from St Petersburg. It is possible to do the trip by hydrofoil - which we did on our return trip - and this was fun. Recommended!

Great to see - but too many people. After seeing the Hermitage and the Faberge Museum, I am not 100% sure the pleasure of seeing all of the beautiful rooms and treasures was worth the hassle.The gardens are beautiful. The treasures are amazing. And the decor is decadent to say the least. But there are crowds, and a long wait to get in.The bad news is that you can't take photos inside. The good news is that once you have fought your way in, and survived the fight to drop your bags, the rest of the way around the museum is very orderly. It is not crowded as numbers are controlled, but you are encouraged to keep moving.

Don't miss the Amber Room. Another don't miss on your tour of St Petersburgh. The Amber Room was beyond what you could ever imagine. The only draw back was that it rained and we did not get to enjoy the garden and fountains. So plan on giving yourself time to spend in the gardens especially on a sunny day

An amazing Palace and gorgeous grounds. Peterhof is the palace of palaces when you visit St. Petersburg. It is actually about an hour drive from the city center. It is enormous, ornate, and surrounded by a beautiful garden and park. It is amazingly beautiful from the inside and the outside and, as with most of the palaces and museums in St. Petersburg, in order to fully appreciate this palace you must visit it as part of an organized tour group with a knowledgeable tour guide.

worth the effort. Some friends of ours took us to this place as if you don't have transport it is a bit of a trip from the city centre.We went on a Sunday so it was very busy and the queue to get tickets to get in was long despite there being many booths.The gardens are well kept and its very clean and tidy the fountains alone were with a look.Beware though of the prices of things as we got one small scoop of ice cream and it was 150 rumbles so if you have a family be prepared to spend.To go inside the main museum building there was another queue for tickets this one was an hour and 20 mins. The tour itself is guided and you are given an ear piece so you can hear the guide but it is only in Russian. In each room though there is a small notice where you can read in English. It was worth going inside to look at what has been restored especially since it was gutted during the war, to see the before and after photos is just astonishing.

Incredible Opulence. It is hard to imaging the wealth of the Russian Romanov family. This was obviously supported by an 80% serf population. This is a must see. It is worth the 45 minute drive from downtown and a privately guided tour is recommended. Of equal stature are the gardens and fountains. We visited the palace in the rain but the impression of the garden and fountains was overwhelming. Go early if you can, and a rainy day might be a mixed blessing with respect to crowds.

Beautiful castle and gardens. Took the 40 minute hydrofoil near the bridge next to the Hermitage. The boats run every 30 minutes and crossing are 40 minutes. Once you get off the boat, you must purchase a ticket, this ticket is for the gardens only and A SINGLE ENTRY ONLY. Once your are at the palace, you must line up again to purchase tickets to visit the palace. It is very confusing and of course no one speaks English and no one is helpful including the police! They all point at different lines. We finally found the right line, and purchased our tickets. They were asking some folks for passports, but we were not asked for ours. Therefore, just in case bring your passports. The palace is very nice and well worth all the hassle. They make you wear slippers over your shoes to protect the floors, be careful as once you wear these the floor is slippery. The guided tours are only in Russian, therefore bring your guide book for references. We then asked if we could see the back gardens, we could see tourists walking around from the palace tour, we were told that it was free to visit that garden, but in order to get back to the pier, we would have to purchase another ticket to get back on the grounds, therefore the back garden is not free if you have to take the boat back. The whole thing is a scam to make you pay again. We therefore did not see the fountains on the back side of the palace, you would think that they would let you go out from the palace, since we purchased a palace ticket. The gardens and fountains are very beautiful and everything is clean and well manicured. They have some snacks available and a couple restaurants and clean bathrooms.

Just Brilliant!. We accessed the Peterhof area via the hydrofoil service from central St Petersburg and were immediately struck by the impressive palace (indeed the Russian equivalent of Versailles!) with the lovely gardens and the engineering marvel that is the gravity fed fountain arrangement. A quick look at the photos published online should be enough to encourage you to visit and see it all for yourself!

Amazing architecture!. A must visit day trip from st petersburg, this palace museum has some of the most beautiful gardens & fountains.
