They were designed years ago without any use of mechanical motors but the water flows freely by way of it's design.Truly amazing! Very chilly place do take an extra jacket.

Stunning Gardens. Very easy to get to on hydrofoil from St Petersburg, 40 minutes. Frequent services available.Gardens and fountains are spectacular and it's a must visit. Didn't go into the palace as managed to visit on Monday, which is cleaning day so house closed!

An impressive palace. When you look at the golden statues and fountains at the lower garden of Peterhof, you can feel the power they are demonstrating. Amazing place, worth an hour drive from the city to see it.

Dirty. You can run through this -there is no such thing as a leisurely stroll and enjoying what you are taking in. It is way too crowded at any given time. People push in the group line and the people at the door are overwhelmed. We used the restrooms here and my little girl did not want to touch anything. It was the dirtiest bathroom I had ever seen in my life. The grounds were not really clean either. I was a little disappointed in this attraction. This was also overrun with Asian tourists.
Summer Palace. Built by the Czar Peter the Great a great palace. Much smaller rooms though. You are obliged to wear shoe covers in order not to damage the wooden floors. Great garden with sprinklers.
another gem. yet more to amaze and astound you a visit to this takes a bit of time as it is further out of city is another must do.

Peterhof is beautiful and crazy - a real must see. It's called the Russian Versailles for good reason. A beautiful palace with far more fountains than Versailles which are actually kept on all day. People have loads of fun in the 'trick' fountains where a guy turns the water on to get you wet and the rest of the fountains take your breath away.It's about a half hour drive away from St Petersburg but well worth the trip. I believe you can get a boat from near the Hermitage which we'd have happily caught but we were driven there by a guide. Honestly, it's a real must-see!

Fantastic palace and gardens. Spectacular building, please be aware if you have a pacemaker you cannot go in the palace. The security within is high and any hand movement above the ropes sets off the alarm. The staff all around are very aggressive in attitude and definately do not smile. The structure walls and ceilings are adorned with gold. The room layouts are fantastic however you need to rely on memory as no photos are allowed. The fountains in the gardens are fantastic where you can take pictures and would look beautiful on a sunny day. The palace is very busy and you need to be ready to cope with queuing
A must see for every one visiting St. Petersburg. This place is one of the most popular and famous tribute to Peter I founded by him and preserves for 300 years.

Cheerful colourful fabulous place . From best touristic attractions in Saint-Petersburg where you can enjoy sky, sea, trees, golden statues and fabulous architecture of palace and fountains. very romantic place to go with the one u love and enjoying squirrels running around and u can feed them too. My recommendation to start there from early morning as the place very big and need minimum 4 hours to discover it.

Gardens, fountains, palaces...all separate paid entry, great on a sunny day. So, to be clear, this is a location with a variety of things to do, each with separate paid entry. Keep in mind that this region only gets something like 60+ days of sunshine every year, and walking through a huge garden may not be as enticing if you're doing it in constant rain...try to pick the sunniest day of your trip to go here. We used a rental car to come here (against the advice of what turned out to be outdated travel books) and it was easy. Google Maps took us right to an entrance (not the main one, which was actually super nice). We parked for free on the street and had zero issues.You pay to enter the gardens, which include sprawling grounds with a large variety of gravity fountains (like at Versailles, they run completely based on wider/narrower pipes, and have been functioning without power for hundreds of years with only refurbishment). The fountains were fun and beautiful. Be sure to see the trick fountains, where locals bring their children to play on sunny/warm days. There are many paths to follow, and it's easy to miss some of the fountains if you're not paying attention. I'd recommend saving a pic of the grounds from online before you go, to make it easier to navigate through. Beware, if you leave the gardens, they probably won't let you reenter for free, even if it's the same day...so don't accidentally walk out of any exits. There are opulent cascading fountains and beautiful terraced fountains in front of the Grand Palace. There are large fountains with sea gods and small fountains with mini sea-cherubs (they are like babies with split fish tails). We also saw a wonderful pyramid shaped fountain that was surrounded by channels of water that drained out and back into the river source. You see channels of water flowing throughout the property, cutting across fields of grass or other plants. It's pretty darn cool. Then, you have several separate palaces or buildings, each requiring paid entry. So, you can pick and choose what you might like to add on, depending on what you want to see and how much grief you want to deal with to buy tickets or see the attraction itself. All will require you put on shoe covers, and all prohibit photography.The Grand Palace is the place for opulence and over the top decor, and is the largest building on the property. See my review on that specific attraction to understand the hoops you'll have to go through to see this place, because oh, yes, there are many hoops. Be prepared to wait in lengthy lines, deal with crowds inside, probably not have an English speaking tour guide (you can self guide), and no air conditioning.Marly Palace is a more subdued two story building. It's smaller, but features all of the rooms you'd expect in any nice home. Kitchen, bedroom, office, etc. Quick to get a ticket for entry and fairly quick to see. A small but okay collection of art from various places outside of Russia (French, Dutch, Flemish, German). You can purchase a combined ticket to see Marly Palace and Peterhof Hermitage (see description below...this is NOT the Hermitage you'll see in St. Petersburg).The Peterhof Hermitage is a small two story building that served one purpose. It was a dining room for Peter the Great and his guests that was closer to the water's edge (the Gulf of Finland), so it was cooler during summer. It's oddly surrounded by a moat (for when you don't want gatecrashers?). The first floor is the kitchen and the second is the dining room. The really awesome part of this place is that they use a pulley system to raise and lower the dining room table and individual place settings. That way, they could send up the entire dinner without having a bunch of servers running around. When a diner finished their plate, they could pull a string to ring a bell and let them know to clear away their dish. They demonstrate this pulley system 3 times a day (I think, it may be 2), and fixed times. We missed that, unfortunately, because the time we read online was wrong. We thought it would be at 3pm, and it had happened at 2pm. This was, for us, the most entertaining of the three buildings. It was easy and fast to get into and showed us something we'd never seen before.Overall, we really enjoyed Peterhof and would recommend it to anyone. Oh,they also have a cafe (no air conditioning, but they have beer!) and a small food cart with seating around it. But, if you're a planner, you could bring a picnic lunch.

Amazing place - ruined by the red tape. This is a beautiful palace and gardens but ruined by the utterly farcical ticketing and entrance system. The only way to get there is by boat - and it's a dedicated service which only goes to this place and back. So we bought tickets and set off - it takes about 30 minutes. When we got there, there was a truly enormous queue which we couldn't work out what it was for. After asking around it turns out the boat ticket doesn't include the entrance to the grounds! So we had to queue up again - and the pace was glacial. Each person was taking about 2-3 minutes to be served, and there were around 100 people in front of us, across about 5 counters... it took an age to get through. After getting in we walked around the grounds a while but it started heavily raining so we headed for the palace itself. But there was yet another massive queue to get into that too! My wife went to ask what the system was and she was told that you have to queue up but you don't get in right then, they only let people in between certain hours - you get allocated a time slot. At that time it was about 1pm, but we were told people queuing now would only be getting in around 4pm - so we abandoned it all and went back to the wharf to go to the hotel. The final insult was then to find out the boat ticket was only one way and we had to queue AGAIN to buy the return ticket!Why on Earth they don't sell just one ticket when you get on the boat for the whole place is beyond me - and even more amazing they didn't sell return tickets (it's not like you can stay there or go from the place to anywhere else). I lovely place totally ruined by a pointless, frustrating and inefficient system.

Smaller palace but big style. The gardens are magnificent and you could spend a day wandering throughout them. Very crowded and the lines weave through the rooms slowly. Try to visit early in the day.

a place where luxury and beauty are perfectly harmonized. This is the place where luxury and beauty are perfectly harmonized. Every single detail is well considered, that's why it is so impressive . One can easily feel the way of life of kings and noble leaving style . I loved the garden which is located just in the beach .... with splendid alleys and gold plated statues .... Fountains and Joke places makes the garden really fascinating. The traveler is recommended to go there before 9Am to see the fountain start with nice anthem of city and will have time to buy ticket to the main palace.

Impressive even in the rain. The term 'White nights' can make you forget that St P is on the same latitude as the Shetland Islands i.e. the weather can be force to contend with. Our hydrofoil trip was cancelled because of the constant driving wind and rain (for five days straight). In fact, cruise ships had to be diverted. Even under raincoats and umbrellas, the gardens of this palace were enjoyable to walk around in, and we kept thinking how much better it would have been on a sunny day. The Palace is a marvel of reconstruction. The experience itself, however, is quite trying, as it is simply packed solid with bus loads of tour groups, struggling to check in coats (obligatory), retrieve coats, visit toilets, and then get moved on from room to glorious room in a tight queue formation until you are disgorged at the end. And there are many rooms to get through. One palace at St P is probably worth doing but on balance, taking into account the crowds, there are many other pleasures to enjoy.

More impressive . The fountains and gardens are even more impressive than Versailles. Access to the grand palace was impossible due to the queues and limited ticketing times, but there are enough distributed museums to still satisfy ones curiosity. Food inside comes at reasonable prices. We used metro and mini bus to get there, which was quick on a Sunday.

Absolutely stunning. This place is amazing. Must see in your visit to St. Petersburg. We went there by boat and it was a nice experience as well. Worth to hire a professional guide to help to skip the line. The palace and the fountains are the main attraction. We did not visit the grouts.

Alla Tours - Peterhof and Hydrofoil. We did a pre-arranged tour with Alla Tours, the St Petersburg 2 day Grand Tour. Included was a hydrofoil ride to the Peterhof from one of the many docks on the Neva river. This is not bus seating, but leather swivel chairs in a 2x2 format with more than adequate room for standing or walking. If you do get a chance to ride in one, check out the nose area first as there are seats with fantastic views up front.The main attraction at the Peterhof is the grounds around the palace area. Almost fully restored from WWII damage, it is impressive. The grounds are perfectly manicured with breathtaking statuary – most having been buried and hidden by the staff prior to the German occupation and use of the Peterhof as a headquarters building. Now the statuary is restored to it’s former position and the most impressive, around the fountain area, has been re-gilded. Based on our timetable, we were only able to see a small portion of the grounds. A full day would be required to see the whole thing in detail.

A Beautiful Place to Wander and Explore!. This was one of the highlights of our trip to St. Petersburg. This well worth the trip outside the city. The palace itself is a golden beauty. But the real beauty are the fountains and garden that surround the palace. Looking up at the palace from the lower gardens you can see the wonder of the place and design marvel that is Peterhof. This was all done with no mechanized pump system and using gravity itself. The fountains are not only a beautiful outdoor treat but the younger people can frolic in some of them discovering the wonders of the whimsical side of Peter.Take the trip to Peterhof! You won't be disappointed!!!

Amazing. Although it was raining and we only visited the gardens and fountains it was an amazing visit. We were all soaking wet in spite of wearing the plastic ponchos our thoughtful tour guide Maria had provided, but we did not stop until we saw everything.

A BEAUTIFUL PLACE TO VISIT. This is a Palace and a museum type attraction. It was a lovely hot sunny day when my family and I had a visit which really added to the experience as the gardens are amazing. Be careful not to touch anything inside the palace as they are very fussy, actually there are a lot of fat Russian women that flick their wooden fans at you if you even put a finger out, a bit like the headmaster and they seem to be deadly accurate. However if you do venture to it a really nice time is in store and it is worth it.

Visit while its sunny. There is not much to say as the Peterhof is already well known worldwide and it deserves its perfect reputation. I would only recommend to read up before you go there. And when there make sure to get a map of the park to figure out how to navigate. Simply marvel at all you see.

Sensational. Part of 2 day ship tour....interesting drive through countryside. Nothing prepares you for the grand scale...gardens and palace. You need to have a guide to explain the history of Peter the great and the development of gardens...spectacular water features flowers waterfalls etc....sneaky water surprises!!!Watch out for pickpockets!

Beautiful fountains and a lovely walk. We only visited the outside. Many people (especially around the palace) but crowds thinned in other areas. Beautiful fountains. Wheelchair accessible but we never found the wheelchair accessible washroom although there is supposed to be one. The interior is not supposed to be accessible but there are other palaces which are more spectacular that wheelchair users can visit.

Stunning!. A magnificent building full of beauty, extraordinary restoration following its ruin in WW2. The many rooms including State and more homely are exquisite, beautiful fabrics, crystal chandelier and artworks. Outside the fountains are quite unique, they are switched on at 11:00 with great fanfare and to music, then walking around the grounds to enjoy the other fountains and eventually the Baltic. Highly recommend.
Amazing . This is amazing place must see you would love it how they build something like this few hundreds years ago .This is all day trip include the castle and the park attached .

Oh to be King....or Queen. This is a must see attraction. Looking at this place makes you realise why when people had no food there was a revolution! It is an unbelieveable place, fully restored after being ruined during the second world war. I walked around with my mouth wide open most of the time looking at the unbelievable grandure. The fountains, waterfall and views are breathtaking, the grounds are well woth the long walks. A guide is recommended but even without one the place will impress and the history amaze you.

Land of fountains and gold. Grand place to visit. Gardens, fountains, gold etc. Museum inside the Palace full of objects full of historical values and knowledge.
Outside in one of the smaller buildings a cappella quire is performing magnificent tunes in the spectacularly acoustic hall.
Beyond stunning.. This Palace of Peter the Great is a true masterpiece. The decor, the opulence, the gardens and the fountains are as stunning as Versailles. A must see if you are in St. Petersburg.

DAZZLING AND CAPTIVATING. Peterhof is a great summer residence created for Russian Emperor Peter the great in the beginning of the 18th century. It has a splendid park on the shore of the Baltic sea with more than 150 fountains. It also comprises beautiful palaces which are more beautiful than their French counterpart. It is decorated by the biggest system of water cascades and fountains and golden sculptures. The focal point is the dazzling cluster of golden statues spouting water in the centre of the palaces. It goes on and on towards the Baltic sea with huge gardens with trick fountains, pyramid fountains, marble structures and intriguing displays.The entire complex is so beautiful that it simply takes your breath away and you want to go there again and again. I would love to go to Russia again just to spend some more time on this heaven on earth.

Eye-popping Opulence. We took the hydrofoil over (these can be gotten behind the Hermitage) and a cab back. Immediately after getting off the hydrofoil, you must purchase tickets to the lower garden before going any further. When we were there, it was cold and rainy (mid-June). Lots of people, but lots of space to spread out. Grounds were beautifully manicured and in better weather, it would be nice to spend more time wandering around. There are kiosks selling some food, trinkets, umbrellas, etc. As you near, stop for photos from the bridges with Peterhof in the background. Fountains are like nothing I have ever seen. The are supplied with water from the Gulf of Finland. We exited through the Upper Garden (no fee to walk through). You will not be disappointed with the grandeur and excessive brilliance of Peterhof's fountains and gardens.

Amazing palace and parklands!. Peterhof is a must-see of SPB! The tour through the palace is great, and the palace has an amazing past including being destroyed by the Nazi's and re-built to original details. The gardens are also beautiful and well worth the walk-through. Highly recommended!
The Peterhof Gardens are amazing. Absolutely beautiful gardens with spectacular fountains. This is a must see in Russia. They have been compared to Versailles, but I think they are even better.
Unlimited richness - reconstracted. It is interesting, that the present regime is reconstructing fatefully the past Czar abundant wealth.

I thought I was in France . It is a stunning palace with great views and gardens. There are a lot of steps but the fountains are worthseeing from the bottom of the steps. It is a copy of French palaces and possibly better. Outside are lots of stalls. The rooms are decadent and show how power can be abused. You have to wear slippers and check bags,coats etc. It's worth the hassle

Beautiful palace!. We recently visited Peterhof palace, when we were in St Petersburg on a cruise holiday. The palace is stunningly beautiful as are the grounds. The opulence that is displayed here is extreme beyond belief. The fountains in the grounds have to be seen as they are magnificent and the inside of the palace is incredible. We unfortunately arrived during a local holiday and along with several other cruise ships, therefore it was extremely busy, which prevented us from being able to stop and read the information available for all of the separate rooms inside the palace.This may also have contributed to the terrible attitude that the taff at the palace had.They were rude, seemed very unhappy and were very short tempered with visitors, not just in our group. At one point a member of our group was pushed along by a very grumpy woman staff member with a fan and snapping her fingers. Not a very nice impression to give to visitors. the queue at the palace were to gain entry for visitors from cruise ships, which were pre-arranged were excessively long also, better organisation is required here.Overall we enjoyed the palace but not the staff or the queues.

Peterhof. We visited as part of a tour package. Remember you must have your own visa, or be on a prearranged your with an authorised company. Expect to queue. Another fine example of detailed restoration. The opulence and ostentation is very interesting.

Wonderful Palace & Gardens. A most delightful Golden Palace with beautiful gardens and the famous fountains. If in St Petersburg this is definitely one of the sites you really must visit. But go as early as you can as it gets really busy.

Russia's Versailles. We loved this palace more than Catherine's Palace in Pushkin. Go early before the crowds. Be sure to be in the gardens at 11:00 am when the fountains are turned on. The gardens are extensive and beautiful. Try the cherry juice for a refreshing drink. Dip a toe in the Baltic.

Peter IS Great!. Built for Peter the Great. It was damaged by Nazis during the Great War and restored to its former glory after the war. An easy boat ride will get you to this rival to Versailles. Opulent water gardens with fantastic fountains and a spectacular palace.

Come for the gold, stay for Peter's favorite retreat. The grounds of the Peterhof itself were lovely, especially on this sunny early summer day. The most spectacular part of the estate, and the most familiar from photographs, was the formal French garden with its Grand Cascade and fountains, ingeniously powered by gravity, rather than by pumps. They were all on display, and the spray was refreshing. During the Nazi occupation, the classical statues, bronze with dazzling gilding, had been hidden successfully by the retreating palace staff – all except the central statue-font of Samson wrestling a lion, which had been too heavy. The Germans had cut up the original for the metal, so the one I saw was a replica, albeit an artful one. Here and there around the grounds were the “surprise” fountains, which spurted up to soak guests who stepped on a particular rock or reached across a table for a piece of fruit from a central bowl. These built-in practical jokes were fashionable in early 18th Century European courts. On this particular warm Sunday, children were jumping exuberantly from rock to rock, spraying each other. My favorite part was “Mon Plaisir,” the relatively modest retreat where Peter the Great liked to live quietly with his wife when imperial obligations didn’t demand that he occupy the Grand Palace here or his winter palace in St. Petersburg. Because he liked things Dutch, he modeled Mon Plaisir after Dutch merchants’ homes, lined the kitchen and some other rooms in blue and white Delft tiles (some were also from a factory he established to produce Dutch-style tiles in Russia) and hung the walls with paintings of bucolic and nautical scenes by minor Dutch artists. With its terrace overlooking the Gulf of Finland and, on clear days, the city on the opposite shore, this must have been a restorative retreat from the pressures of court life.

More Gold and Opulence Than One Can Imagine. You come away with a clear picture why the Russians finally killed off the Tsar and his family. It was obvious they did not give a damn about the common man. You can learn a tremendous amount about Russian history, especially how TB plagued even the aristocrats. An absolute necessary visit.

The Grand Cascade and Fountain ,Stunning .. The largest of Peterhof's palaces looks truly imposing when seen from the Lower or Upper Gardens, represent Russia's victory over Sweden in the Great Northern War.Look at the grand palace and the garden and the majestic fountains (64) and the grand cascade

OMG - arrive before 11 to watch the fountains begin!. Insane water fountains!!!Insane.The view and setting amongst the palace are incredible, although the crowds are large. Arrive before 11 and get a good spot along the metal railing to see the fountains begin. Well worth the travel to the suburbs of the city.

Overrated, overcrowded, overpriced, incomprehensibly organized.. This was a big disappointment! We had looked at the website for information and found what we could. We knew of individual times for entry. We were not allowed to purchase tickets to the palace on-line, however. Why? We had no idea. We took the hydrofoil and arrived at 11:30 am, to complete chaos. First, we had to pay park entry. One can purchase no other tickets at the entrance. But, the confusion and lack of information is staggering. We were provided no map, nor could we find one anywhere we asked. Once we purchased the park entry ticket we went straight to the palace to purchase the entry ticket for it. The line was two hours long and that was the only window of time until later in the day. So, we wandered the park only to find many other options of buildings to see, all requiring a high fee, especially the church. We inquired about how to purchase a combined ticket but no one speaks English anywhere. The best we could figure out is that there is no combined ticket. Everywhere we went we saw people trying to figure out what to do and not paying a separate entry fee for the other buildings because the fees are exorbitant. So, we entered none of these buildings and came back to get in line for purchasing tickets for the afternoon entry time. We discovered the on-line information to be incorrect and found a line for individuals that was allowed in with the groups. We chatted with a Russian in this line who complained that even he had not been able to figure it out. He had waited in the first line for an hour and a half and not been allowed to buy a ticket. It is inexcusable but we finally realized that only groups are welcome here. Entry for individuals is made as difficult as possible in order to discourage them. And, to top it all off, the “free” upper gardens are not free at all. Once you have entered the lower gardens you cannot leave and return. But, the only way to see the upper gardens is to leave. So, no one who takes the water route can see them without paying two entry fees. Ridiculous! Yes, there are fountains and nice grounds, but they were not worth the trip. Neither was the palace. Once you’re inside, it is overcrowded; you are squeezed through along with large guided groups so you can hardly get a chance to see anything, though the wholly re-created interiors are splendid. Even the tour groups looked bored, and were going so quickly through the palace, that they could not have enjoyed the harried experience either.Save your sanity and go to another palace.

Must see. Even though it is outside the city, one can take a tour or boat to get there. Our guide did a wonderful job telling about how life was inside. Many pictures that help. Gardens were nice but it was raining and hard to enjoy.

Do Not Miss Peterhof!. We thought Versailles in Paris was the most amazing, beautiful and historic place in the world... That is until we visited Peterhof! The gardens, the water elements, the palace are like nothing else we have ever seen! Wish we could have stayed longer. Go with a tour guide to get the best information and background.

Baltic Cruise. Guided tour by Alla Tours. Part of a 3 day stay in St Petersburg. This is a must see place and grounds. Our guide, Alex, was extremely informative which made the experience even more enjoyable. We were part of a small group of 16 who had signed up with Alla Tours to experience the historical sights - including Catherines Palace, The Hermitage, St Isaacs Cathedral, St Peter and Paul's Fortress, The Church of the Savior on the Spilled Blood and the Yusupov Palace - where Rasputin was murdered. An excellent 3 day tour - we could have stayed longer, but the ship would not have waited!

Possibly not worth the journey just for a visit to the gardens. We went on a 30 minute hydrofoil boat trip to the Peterhof palace and gardens on a chilly and wet afternoon. As with all visits in St Petersburg, this was a very busy location with dozens of tour groups. Our visit was to the gardens only – more space to spread out and on a warm sunny day would have been very pleasant.But although it was sort-of interesting to see the exterior of the buildings (and the gardens were quite decent), it would have been a better use of our time to have skipped this event and spend more time at the other better locations.

Magnificent Fountains and Beautiful Palace. My wife and I toured Peterhof Palace and Park in early May 2016. Peterhof Palace began construction in about 1710 when Peter the Great (Peter I, 1682-1725) outlined the location of a palace and a short canal through a park to the Gulf of Finland. In 1716, the park grounds were expanded and, after Peter I had visited Versailles in France, Peter decided to have water features to outdo those in France.There are essentially three main sections of Peterhof, (1) the front gardens, (2) the palace, and (3) the lower park grounds. The gardens located at the front of the Palace are extensive and more like formal English gardens with geometric layouts. trees and bushes trimmed to elaborate shapes, some ponds and fountains. It is a far more impressive front entrance to the Palace than that of the entrance to the Palace of Versailles. There are five ponds in the front garden with various fountains in the centers with statues of Apollo, Neptune (in the Neptune Fountain), cupid and 4 other marble statues (in the Oak Fountain), Venus Italica (in the Western Square fountain) and Apollino (in the Eastern Square fountain). The Great Peterhof Palace is ENORMOUS! The outside is tastefully painted a pale yellow with white trim. There is not the extensive and gaudy gold gilding that is in the Catherine Palace except that the domes above the chapel and the dome at the other end of the Palace are gold gilded. It sits high up on a hill overlooking a park full of fountains and a canal that runs a short distance to the Gulf of Finland. There are many, many rooms but photography is not permitted inside the Palace (I assume to make sure you buy the books at the souvenir shop). The books are actually quite good and contain lots of color photos. The Main Staircase is covered with much gilded gold carvings and gold statues. The Ballroom is a gorgeous room of 2,900 sq. feet covered with gold gilded carvings, gold gilded framed mirrors, and a large ceiling painting called Mount Parnassus (painted 1751). It has a beautiful inlaid patterned wooden floor. Although the overwhelming amount of gold in the room gives a gaudy feeling to the room, it is still a stunning and gorgeous room. Other rooms in the Palace are also lovely and they do not have that overwhelming gold and gaudy sense that Catherine's Palace has. There is a Blue Reception Room where clerks kept records of activities at the palace. The Throne Room is a lovely room which is mostly white with light green painted accents with red curtains and red carpeted steps by the red velvet throne chair. Above the throne is a large portrait of Catherine the Great (Catherine II) in a green suit and mounted on her white horse, Brilliant. This green suit is preserved in the special access room in the Hermitage Storage rooms, The White Dining room is beautifully done in white with white stucco work with light blue accents. The large dining table is set with Wedgwood china for 30 (?) people. There are also boudoir rooms, divan rooms, dressing rooms, game rooms, a blue drawing room, and a bedroom. The most interesting (an pleasantly restful) room is Peter the Great's study which is covered with wooden panels with decorative carvings and an inlaid patterned wooden floor. Not all of the rooms were available for touring but the sense is that this Palace is better suited for living than Catherine II's palace with all of its opulence and gilding. The most stunning part of Peterhof is its lower park with its numerous fountains, statues, canal, small buildings, flowers and walkways. The fountains are activated from 11 am to 5 pm because they are fed by gravity from ponds higher up on the hill. The Great Cascade flows down the hill from just behind the Palace and there is water everywhere spouting from statues, ground fountains, and ending in the Scoop Basin with the golden statue of Samson holding open the jaws of a gold lion with a huge spout shooting high up out of the mouth of the lion.The sculpture on the cascade is 250 gold gilded pieces, 30 of which are also fountains. On each side of the Scoop Basin are collonades with flower gardens in front of each. The park is extensive with many exciting fountains, cascades, gardens and other buildings. In my opinion, although not as large as Versailles (maybe), it is well designed, with interesting features through out. It is very peaceful even with the hordes of people everywhere. We did not get through all of the Lower Park as it was just too extensive and we simply didn't have the time. Peterhof is a place that should not be missed. It would be easy to spend an entire day at Peterhof.
Lovely place. Great place to look around and the gardens are just amazing. Did get extremely crowded and were warned about pickpockets continually so extreme care needed. Worth a visit for sure.

You can't visit St Petersburg and not go!. A Truly amazing place. The gardens, the palaces, the fountains are a site to behold. Take the Hydrofoil to the grounds. Don't miss the trick fountains. Take your time, there's much to see. Don't , I repeat, don't forget your camera. Hope you have a sunny day

Beyond description. Has to be seen to be believed. Do not miss this unique venue. It is truly magnificent. The large grounds can accommodate the crowds. Good approached by hydrofoil = it was designed to be approached by sea.

Garden of Eden. Such a beautiful garden this is. Fontains and statues all over. The place can be very crowded. Fee for non russians is 700rHow to get there:The minibus at Avtovo metro station can be very busy. In our case there was already a line and people were cramped in the van. That's why we took a taxi from this station, for only 600r. That's still a real bargen compared to the boats.Food:Food is awfull at the park. For example: chicken roll 270r, but that's nothing more than a wrap with a piece of chicken. When you want the whole thing/toppings (some ugly bacon, cheddar and a occasional cucumber slice) the price goes up to almost 500r. Outrages considering it has zero tast

Splendid Royalty . The royalty well preserved and displayed the rich heritage and culture of the Russian history The main hall , fountains and the gardens well preserved and maintained .....one has to visit it and know the history and see the heritage....

Picturesque. This Palace is over the top. The inside is impressive but it's the gardens and fountains that will impress you the most. You can's miss the inside but take extra time walking around the gardens and around all the fountains. Arrive early too. We got run over by the crowds when they opened it up to the people that didn't have pre-arranged times.

Over the Top. Peterhof is so over the top. The palace and the gardens. If I had to choose one over the other it would be the gardens. After you see several of the palaces all gilded in gold in Russia this is more of the same. The gardens and fountains are what captivated me. You can spend a good 2 hours just enjoying all the fountains and the grounds covered with beautiful flowers and various sculptures. Make time to see the entire garden as you will be more than glad you did.

Depends on the weather. There are two hydrofoil lines from behind the Hermitage to Peterhof. It appears they share landing docks and ticket return ticket boots at the P. If the weather is less than good, they sell one-way tickets to P and give no indication how to get back if the water conditions are choppy and the boats don't run. Unhelpful and even hostile staff. We did make it to the dock of P and the weather was not good enough to even venture up to the fountains. Purchasing return tickets was a major challenge. So, I can't say anything about the P. And I appreciate you'd like to ride the hydrofoil. I suggest you skip the P and go instead to Catherine Palace. Your research will indicate that CP is a better place to visit than P.

Gardens. Just visited the gardens. Went by hydrofoil from St Petersburg, easy journey, you board opposite the Admiralty. Gardens park like with fountains and walks through the trees. No flowers to speak of. The palace amazing to look at with fountains, gold statues and tourists!Well worth a visit.

Brilliant!. Visited the gardens one sunny but chilly afternoon in June. The gardens are beautiful We walked for about two hours and enjoyed the layout and the beautifully constructed fountains of every type. There are surprise fountains that sprinkle on you in certain places. There are beautiful Roman and Greek fountains. But the most spectacular is the one directly behind the palace - a large construction that leads to the bay of Finland.

Brilliant and what opulence.... Created at the will of Peter the Great as a counterpart of Versailles, is 30 kms from St. Petersburg on the shore of the Gulf of Finland. We visited Peterhof Upper and Lower fountain gardens, then toured the Grottos of the Grand Cascade tour (where the tour took us behind the main cascade of Peterhof to see how the fountain system operates). Don't miss the start of the water show in the morning. We also visited Monplaisir Palace of Peter the Great (the only authentic building in Peterhof that was not destroyed by the Nazis during WWII). Superb.

How did they do it. This palace/museum was fantastic, not just for the over-the-top decorations, but the amazing series of fountains which did not have pumps and were run using gravity feed - and the original pipes were wooden and the technological applications used more than 200 years ago indicated that these people had far more intelligence and skills than we would have believed. Some of the trick fountains were most enjoyable and children in particular loved them. The grounds are magnificent and all in all it was a most enjoyable day.
Amazing Fountains. Gardens, fountains and sly waterworks! Lovely hour's walk. Fascinating photos of war destruction and rebuilding. Take the hydrofoil back to the city.

Gardens are Fantastic!. We had a very full day in St. Petersburg so only had time to see the gardens of Peterhof. There were fantastic and definitely worth the trip from St. Petersburg. I am sure that the Palace is also great, but just spending an hour looking at the gardens and seeing the outside of the Palace is well worth the time.

Opulent Palace, Lovely Grounds. You may have seen enough of opulent Russian palaces by the time you get here, but the 40 minute hydrofoil ride is worth it just for the grounds and fountains. Peter knew how to live.

Need to see. A very interesting place to see very beautifully restored property which was destroyed also by germans....but it is back of its glory from the time of peter the great...need to take the fast boat ride of about 30 min to get there but worth it.

Very rushed tour. We went on a tour mainly to see the fountains. The palace itself was typically over the top with lots of gold leaf everywhere and you are really aware of why there was a revolution when you see such splendour. After the tour of the palace we were told to enjoy the gardens and fountain display. There really wasn't enough time to do both. We had to rush our viewing ofthe gardens in order toe in position or the display. The fountains are not flowing all the time so you have to be in position to get a good view before the display starts. They have almost military style Russian music and the cascades build as the music builds. Very thrilling but immediately after we had to rush back to get on the tour bus. We had to ignore all the stalls which sold beautiful headdresses as we were told the coaches would leave on time even if we weren't on the bus! While walking through the gardens we did see a ferry stop on the jetty. This had come from St Petersburg and if we visit again in ink we will get our own visa and use the ferry.Overall a good tour as we saw a lot but I don't like being so rushed.

Amazing day. Get there early and get ready to queue up.
The small tour of the apartments was great, unfortunately not in English, the main buildings are too busy,
What beautiful fountains and gardens.
The food is poor and expensive, just remember that leaving the park means you can't re enter!

Part of a 2 day tour with TJ travel. It took about an hour by mini bus to reach St Petershoff.
The gardens and fountains are beautiful. The sun was shining the tulips were in bloom and the fountains flowing.
We were given a very informative tour around the gardens and I particularly liked the trick fountains.
Again amazing. We did not go up the steps to the palace but the opulence alone is quite beautiful. A lot to see and the hydrofoil ride was great.

An art piece made by nature and human combined. . We visited the place during June and the weather could not be any worse. There was a thunderstorm. All outside activities were more or less canceled. Despite this, it was really excellent and I cannot imagine how better it can be during good weather. The architecture, statues, fountains, gardens, forest all equally beautiful. I am so glad we went despite the weather.

Peter the Great ... His World. This is Peter the Great's beautiful palace and spectacular gardens, with numerous gravity-driven fountains and statuary. A must-see for visitors to Saint Petersburg. We had tickets to palace and gardens. Loved it all. We visited with a very knowledgable private guide. Even so, our reading about Peter the Great, his life and times, beforehand enhanced the experience. Note: Photo-taking not allowed inside the palace.
A fun place to visit. Beautiful grounds. Lovely fountains and great water features - watch out for the 'trick fountains'. The buildings well worth a visit for the decorations and gold features.
Wonderful Peterhof. A metro then cheap minibus took us to Peterhof. Highly recommend this place - the fountains, palace and ground are truly wonderful

Day adventure. It is excellent place to spend day giant park and museums yes there are many ticket (fee) to get into the different buildings. a must is the main place and of course the Peter and Catherine house. Cost of food can be little pricey like any park. However strong recommend.
Natural Beauty and Creative Construction. Peterhof State Museum is spectacular. The fountains are a marvel of technology and ingenuity. The grounds are beautiful and the tulips so colorful.

Exquisite place . Beautiful grounds and fountains. Gardens and pathways are well groomed and views of the Baltic are beautiful. About a 45 min drive outside of the city. Well worth the trip. The fountains are quite unique.

An amazing insight into a former age . This venue is really worth a visit, which gives an insight into the splendor and opulence of a former age. The history has been expertly preserved and protected so that future generations can learn and experience history.

Favorite attraction in St. Petersburg!. St. Petersburg has a multitude of wonderful sightseeing opportunities but Peterhof captured my heart. Maybe it's because I love strolling outdoors among the greenery and flowers. Perhaps it was due to the beautiful sunny day and all of the lovely fountains. Still, it may have been due to the unexpected sense of humor injected into some of the water features (don't want to spoil the surprise). Whatever the reason, Peterhof dazzled me, and I can think of no better place to spend a lovely sunny day in St. Petersburg. Go-I'm sure you will enjoy it!

Beautiful place but visit in the off season. We were on a Baltic Cities cruise and St. Petersburg was one of our ports. We decided to visit Peterhof. There were probably at least 5 thousand people, this is not an exaggeration, from cruise ships trying to tour this beautiful property at the same time. Luckily the gardens are large and people can spread out but still there are so many people trying to take "selfies" in front of every fountain that it became annoying. You could not get close enough to see the beauty of the craftsmanship of the artists' work. When you do get inside to tour the palace you are only allowed a short amount of time inside each room before the staff ushers you into the next room. I guess they are trying to make sure that the many thousands of tourists can get through the building before they close.My suggestion is that you don't visit during cruise ship season. The only problem with that is that the gardens may not be open or in bloom.

Beautiful fountains . It's best to go to Peterhof on a warm sunny day as the gardens and fountains are beautiful. It costs R700 for entry into the lower garden (the largest), but this doesn't give you access to the top garden behind the palace. The palace itself costs R600 and there are some grand rooms, however you don't get to see much and there are huge tour groups going around which are difficult to get past which can be frustrating. Every building in the palace grounds has a separate fee and you have to keep buying more tickets at each place, they also have different opening and closing times and days. All in all this can really add up so pick what you want to see carefully. This is a must see place as it's really stunning. The opulence is amazing and you see that the minute you walk to the palace. I went there by hydrofoil. This takes about 30 mins and costs R1,300 for a return trip. They go every half hour and you get them from the river embankment in front of The Hermitage. This is the quickest and easiest way, although not necessarily the cheapest.

Stunning setting, fabulous gardens. We took the hydrofoil out to see the Peterhof and were very glad we did. However there are a few quirks you should be aware of. They dont seem to sell one ticket to see the whole of Peterhof. When you come of the dock there are ticket offices (poorly designed and facing sideways so a messy line should be anticipated) they sell tickets to the lower garden. As we went through the turn stile we noticed a sign saying out ticket was good for one entry only, which seemed odd until we discovered that you had to buy another ticket to enter the upper gardens, where th palace is, and another to enter the palace and yet another to get back into the lower gardens to get back to the boat to return to St Petersburg. The smells so strongly of "rip off" that we decided to just visit the lower gardens. The lower gardens are beautiful, with numerous fountains, the most impressive being the one that leads up to the palace, but there are several others throughout the gardens and lovely flower beds and other features as well. We were completely satisfied with just visiting the lower gardens, which are the larger part of the estate.

Beautiful and Fun. The gardens are stunning. Gardens aren't usually fun, but this garden was built with fountains that are secretly triggered and it's fun to watch people unknowingly trigger the water spouts or, try to get past the fountains without triggering the water. I hope to return and be able to spend more time in the gardens.

Versailles with a Russian accent. After a half hour boat ride you enter hundreds of acres of ponds, fountains, gardens and statuary. Absolutely breathtaking and that's before you enter the palace. Exquisite golden decorations and various architectural masterpieces. An absolute must for any visit to Saint Petersburg.
The ultimate. This was the ultimate experience of Tsarist splendour and what royalty in Russia was like in that period you can not miss it

Extraordinary. This is really magnificient preserve. For those visiting Saint Petersburg this is certainly "must see" attraction. It is combination of nice park, beautiful fountains and great palaces. Certainly go and visit Grand Palace. It is not cheap - first you pay to get to the Lower Park and then you pay separate price for each building, so the whole day visit can become costly but it is worth it. There are some weaker points - almost no one speaks English (or any foreign language, so it may be difficult to navigate around. As foreigner you pay more but you can jump the queues (but this is usually written in Russian) - this might be useful in summer particularly when you want to get to Grand Palace. If you come by boat you enter to Lower Park (for which you pay). Upper Park is free but you cannot get there without leaving compound and when you want to go back you must pay again. However, these are small difficulties and the place is exceptional. Fully recommended!

Peterborough Park and gardens.. We visited this wonderful cool and verdant park a little way out of St Petersburg. We were driven there by Igor, who operates Feel Free tours, and without that help, could not have seen all that we did. Well worth the visit to get away from the hustle and bustle of St Petersburg.

Great place to spend a day. The grounds of Peterhof Palace are just as amazing as the inside of the Palace. Be sure to bring you camera ! The history, architecture and décor of the Palace would be worth the tip alone; but the gardens and grounds are beautiful as well. A must see are the many fountains and "small Palaces" throughout the grounds. No long coats or backpacks are allowed so keep that in mind (they have a coat check area). This is a fantastic day trip, I would highly recommend.
One of the finest. Again, not enough time allowed from a cruise but still spectacular. Be there for the start of the fountains, 11:00am. The entire site is worth a day.

A Blaze of Colour. Greets you at every turn - of the weather is kind - at this incredible Summer Palace. What a fine location, personable ambience & playful fountains. An hour out of the city, it is far more romantic than Versailles - spend a day at least to explore the entire grounds.

Amazing park and fountains. If you have seen the Catherine palace skip the inside and go directly to the fountains and park. We spent the day and it was a restful walk through amazing grounds and some of the worlds most beautiful fountains.

WELL WORTH THE BOAT RIDE FROM CITY. Spectacular setting only surpassed by the architecture & beauty of the canals, fountains & buildings. Hard to imagine the pomp & excess that must have prevailed in creating & supporting this venue. Should be one of the 7 Wonders of the World.

Spend more time here and explore the gardens too!. Aside from the Great Palace, the most photographed place in Peterhof must be the Samson fountains and cascade right in front of it. The fountains only start from May through to sometime in October? The canal that runs from the fountains to the sea is a nice walk ending in piers that you can take hydrofoils back to the city in 45 minutes. So, you do not need to take the land route here.Of things we missed - Marly palace and the lower park garden fountains. Definitely need to there too!

Yet to see something as beautiful !!. A must must visit when in St Petersburg..it's totally mesmerizing..plan it as a day trip cuz it's huge with the gardens surrounding it..do enjoy the different fountains in the garden,, u can also view the bay of Finland from the palace grounds.

History felt. Visiting Peterhoff gives you the essence of what it was like at that time in history. To imagine that his daughter had to add to the estate because she felt it was not large enough to house their small family was eye opening. Bankrupting the family to do so was also enlightening. The palace is beautiful and the grounds immaculate. Be sure you witness the fountains going off with the music. Amazing feat as the fountain is all gravity driven. It will be very crowded so I recommend you be one of the first groups through. The female museum guards (only female, huh?) don't look very happy to be there and were not very friendly.
Excellent fountains. Ensure you go there during hours when the fountains are operational. The fountains are the highlight of the preserve which costs RUB 700 to enter.

What can I say? Don't miss Peterhoff. Visited by Hydrofoil (quay behind Winter Palace) which was a great way to travel to Peterhof. The grand palace is simply sumptuous as are the gardens and golden fountains. The lower gardens are a fabulous place to wander around. The only negative is that the entrance fee (700 roubles, May 2016) does not include anything other than the grounds. Each of the many attractions are charged separately. It would be very expensive to enter them all! I would recommend the Marly Cafe at the far right side of the gardens for food. We made the mistake of eating in the restaurant in the centre of the park. It was not good. Strangely the entrance fee did not include a map of Peterhof so I would recommend obtaining one before you go. Overall an excellent and memorable day out from SPB. It does get very crowded so go early!

Another must see. When Peter the Great founded St Petersburg he wanted to create a Venice of the north. With Peterhof he wanted to replicate Versailles. He did a magnificent job. The grounds, with the surprise fountains ( be careful you could walk into the middle of one ) are magnificent. When you see all of the magnificent fountains remember that there are no pumps involved...it is all accomplished by gravity only!
Wonderful gardens & fountains. Amazing display of historical building, gardens and amazing fountains. At 11:00 am daily a waterfall show in front of the main building to music !
APeterhof. This was one of the most amazing places I have ever visited with all the many fountains and it's pure splendour.
Obviously a must see site. You will realize the wealth and power of the Romanov dynasty. A must see site in this city. A bit overwhelming so much to see. SMALL tour you will see more
Magnificent . An assault on the senses I have rarely seen anything as magnificent as the fountains here, quite incredible. The palace incredible, still reeling from the beauty.

Great place to visit on a sunny day. If you have more than one day in SP, you should give it a try. A large beautiful park with 150 magnificent gold-plated fountains? If you have been to any other major palaces (the Hermitage, Catherine's or Pavel's), skip the palace at Peterhof and stroll through the park. You can take a hydrofoil that runs every 30 min from Admiralty embankment (across the street from the Hermitage). The place is very windy, a coat or a schawl is highly recommended even if it is warm in the city.

Fountains that surpass Trevi Fountains. We took the hydrofoil to visit Peterhof, the kingdom of fountains and its gardens. The hydrofoil will reduce your transit time by one hour compared to car/van transportation and when you are touring every hour is critical.. The main fountain is in my opinion more spectacular than Trevi Fountains in Rome and Peterhof is "green". The fountain is 100% powered by water pressure, no pumps are used. If you have the time, there are over 20 museums on the property, although I needed to use my time for the more famous attractions in St Petersburg.

"Spectacular". A short boat ride takes you to this most beautiful summer palace and from the moment you land it takes your breath away. The palace is a spectacular example of the baroque style of architecture, and the sheer opulence of it leaves you in awe. The palace now turned into a museum is indeed very well maintained and organised. The surrounding gardens and the hundreds of hectors of woods dotted with fountains are beautiful and one can spend hours walking around absorbing the fresh and crisp air of the Baltic. A great day spent!

Very busy,but well worth a visit. Went by Hydrofoil approx £7 return,not with a group. Queue for tickets £8 then after a long walk another £6 to enter the palace-no joint tickets are available.Also individual entry/ticket purchase was restricted to certain times[1200-1400]There are also smaller buildings in the park where extra charges are also applied.A whole day would be reasonable here.We did manage entry to the main palace and interior is stunning-allow 45mins.It may be best to visit with a local guide in a small group.

Gaudy But Beautiful. We thought Catherine Palace was grand and extravagant, and then we visited Peterhof Gardens. Man, is this gaudy or what?! But it's gaudy with taste! The garden is designed very beautifully and the golden statures and fountains enhances the beauty. Everything is tastefully done and maintained. Many, many photo opportunities here and do take your time and take in relaxing moments of this wonderful park.

Unbelievably beautiful and be there at noon!. Well worth the hour drive to the palace and the tour inside showing the most lavish extravagances of Catherine The Great, who bankrupted Russia through her over self indulgence.The fountains come on to a fanfare of glorious Russian choir music and then the garden walk is supreme, and if you return by hydrofoil it is even better! Take comfy shoes.
Stunning. Peterhof is stunning and gorgeous. Gold leaf everywhere, and the layout and design are breathtaking. Don't miss this place.

Gorgeous yards!. Really eady to get there. Just take a 'ship/ferry' from front of Hermitage Museum, will take you there in 45 mins. The gardens; fountains they are amaxing... is so big that even is crowded you wont feel it.We went in a nice May morning; weather was sunny and warm. Would say best time to visit the city is by the mid/end of May

May for Peterhof. If you can get a guide for the day to take you, do St. Catherin's palace too. They are close to each other by car. Also a guide will be able to take you under the fountains and see how they work, amazing, you come out inside one of the biggest fountains, watch out they might just switch on!

Ideal place on a warm, sunny day. Although Peterhof swarms with tourists, it is definitely worth a visit. If you have kids, and the weather is warm, they will love the magical fountains and little red squirrels. I recommend taking the hydrofoil through the Gulf of Finland for a little magic and history.

Impressive gardens. We traveled via hydrofoil. It was very busy in the gardens with numerous fountains. We went by tour and were impressed with the expanse and fountains but were disappointed that the tour did not go inside. The outside is 'nice', but without an interior visit we would not go back as we are not garden people.

A must when in St. Petersburg. We took the tourbus and the guided tour was 50 dollars (including the bus ride). Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and I am glad we had a guide. The castle is very impressive and the gardens with the fountains are great. It is hard to believe that there are no pumps to make those fountains work. It is at the Baltic Sea and you can glimpse at the Ocean from the castle. It reminds a bit of Versailles.

Beautiful!!!. So much to see, be prepared to spend some quality time there and get a good guide. Do not skip the gardens and grounds, they are so amazing! The amount of gold will make you question how much Russia has in total, ha!
Spectacular Fountains. Despite being there on a rainy day in April, the gardens and the fountains are amazing. We didn't go inside the Museum so can't comment on that part.

Peterhof Gardens. Peterhof Gardens is part of Peter’s Palace complex (Peterhof) located in St. Petersburg, Russia. Peter the Great was inspired by Versailles palace in France. It was created on this model. The grandeur and opulence is one of a kind and unseen in our Western culture. It is an immense estate almost as large as Orlando, Florida’s Disney theme park. The Grand Cascade is shaped on the French King Louis IX Chateau de Marty’s. It is impressive with multiple fountains and gold statues of Samson. The changing of tree foliage enhanced the gardens' beauty. We enjoyed the trick fountains that rained on us. A white bench dropped a curtain of water suddenly on persons. In addition, adorable ducks swam in a picturesque fountain. Fountains operate without the use of pumps. Water is supplied from natural springs and collects in reservoirs in the upper gardens. The elevation difference creates the pressure that drives all the fountains. . They shared with our group the beauty of Peterhof Gardens.

Impressive. This is quite a museum. Once you see it, you understand why the Russian people hated their leaders. It's nice to see, quite expensive and then you can't get into separate sections unless you pay extra money.

JUST FANTASTIC . It's not easy to reach this place on your own, if you are non russian BUT take a directions from hotel you are staying inWe walked for nearly 5 hours non stop but it was worth it. Every step we walked gave us great satisfaction of seeing something different. There is not a single fountain repeated in this huge complex.Central Part of the Petergof Park is just amazing. Solid Gold (water outlet) and tombs is hard to forgetOnly draw back is toilets are not as many as it should be considering the size of the park

Disappointing attitude towards tourists!. Coming to The last days of our trip in Russia, we decided to visit the spectacular Palace/gardens!.We arrived at the outside ticket office only to get sent from pillar to post before eventually been told that the only way we could get a ticket to enter the palace was by buying first the ticket to enter the gardens! At a price of 700 rubles, in the pouring rain, we really did not want to enter the gardens but only wanted to visit the palace.However, this was not possible and we reluctantly paid as 700 rubles to enter the gardens and watch the Fountains was the rain fell around us.When we went to retain the tickets for the palace itself, we were again pushed from pillar to post before being told, eventually, that we were two hours to early and that we would have to wait until 2 PM before they would let tourists in, after the Russians had had their time to enter!We all found this quite insulting but were quite happy to go back to the original entry gate and grab a coffee and some lunch before returning. This was to be the third disappointment! The ticket allow you into the Gardens, is valid for one entry only get the coffee bar and WC is outside of the ticket barrier. This means that we were left with the choice of either getting our coffee, and a band in the Palace, or standing in the rain and waiting until 2 o'clock before we would eventually be able to purchase a ticket to enter the palace.We all decided that we had had enough for treatment and abandon our visit to the Palace altogether!All of us found this attitude quite insulting on three grounds.1- why is it necessary to pay your ticket to enter the garden when all you want to do is into the palace, without entering the garden!2- why is it a rule that the tourists are not allowed in at the same time as the Russians and are made to wait, in our case in the pouring rain, before being allowed to buy a ticket for entry to the Palace?3 – I also, and I simply cannot understand this one, are we not allowed to the coffee bar after we have entered the garden, simply to buy a coffee or to dry off before re-entering the gates to buy a ticket into the palace.In all, this has been our most disappointing attraction to visit and it is a shame because it has left a bitter taste of our trip to Russia!
Beautiful, inside and out.. Loved the grounds, and inside was just stunning. It was very crowded and the staff tried hard to help us get in and avoid being pushed out by the larger local tour groups.

Inconsistent information about opening hours. It's a nice park, with fountains, but good luck figuring out when they open and close. We call several times to make sure they would be open when we planned to visit. Weirdly we received a different answer every time -- so to play it safe, we visited when all of those had indicated they would be open. In fact, the museum and fountains were closed.

Formal Palace Garden with trick fountains on a very large scale. This should probably be visited between the end of May and late October to see the fountains playing and flowers in bloom as it must be lovely

Spectacular. Peterhof was included as part of our 2 day guided St Petersburg tour. It took around an hour to get there by car but it is well worth it. The building was out of this world and the gardens were beautiful. our guide had warned us that the fountains would not be functioning at the time of year that we visited but to her surprise there were a number that were being tested. We were very lucky to see some with water running. Mon Plasir was not open so we weren't able to see inside that.

great. On the marble obelisk costing at a fencing of the Top garden of Peterhof, are cut figures: 29. The distance in kilometers from St.-Petersburg up to a brilliant country residence of Russian emperors, and nowadays world famous "capitals of fountains" - Peterhof is those.The plan of creation of a country residence which on the luxury would not concede to the French Versailles, has arisen at Peter I in 1714. The kept figures of tsar, its decrees and marks on documents enable to approve, that the general concept of a lay-out of ensemble, and sometimes and detailed development of separate elements of architecture and gushing constructions belong to the founder of Peterhof.

Peterhof St Petersburg. You really need more than a day to do this justice as the area it covers is vast. For a whistle-stop tour then a day is an absolute minimum. The architecture of the beautiful buildings combined with the landscaped gardens is a wonderful sight, a sort of mini Versailles perhaps. Make the effort to see and you will be rewarded.
Amazing! Leaves you speachless!. The combination of timeless architecture and amazing location makes this place so unique and breathtaking!

Chateau de Versailles of Russia!. A serene tranquil place, that is set amidst a huge beautifully lavish green landscape overlooking the river. Fountains are heavenly and walks amongst them make you feel that the sky is the limit. The place is very well taken care of inside out. The museum is so nice. The cruise ride is about an hour or an hour and half and is very smooth. It is a must see when you are in St. Pete!

Amazing post-war restoration of Imperial palace; tearfully bad tour guides. You have 40 minutes to follow along with your official guide on the Palace tour. The interiors are gorgeous and well worth seeing but don't try to inconvenience anyone with questions--you might slow down the tour guide! Ours seemed to be asleep on her feet but had not forgotten her extra dose of grumpy pills. In the summer you can see the beautiful fountains but the place is mobbed; in the winter it's still quite pleasant to stroll in the gardens, but the outlying palaces Monplaisir, Marly etc. will be closed.
glorious estate. Worth the trip on the comfortable hydrofoil. Glorious gardens, meticulous restoration. Fountains! Just gorgeous.

Still worth seeing in winter. The palace is well worth visiting. We are pleased to have a friendly driver and guide both enjoying what they were doing. We hardly book "group tour" but here it was very helpful to have a guide speaking fluent English as even the museum staff would not understand much English. Besides we were lucky to be the only couple in the group and our guide Lida from MariaRose company was not only giving information about the palace but also about daily life or our other interests / questions in detail. Winter means not much for the garden; I'm sure it would be a nice day out during summer months. However, we were lucky that the statues were not covered and we missed only the fountains. We love snow. Thus, we truly enjoyed the garden and walking on thick snow.
Wonderful. A step back in time, very surreal as it almost feels as if it is living in that era and I was looking in such is the grandeur. Magnificent well worth it.

It's great and you can walk on water!!! . We went in deep winter with heavy snow but none the less it was still amazing The interior is spectacular we thought that it's on the same lever as Versilles in France just slightly more real. The grounds are in readable, we can only imagine what it would be in summer but we had it totally covered in snow that made it a little magical. About 500m away is the sea that is totally frozen and easy to walk out on. For an Aussie that was a real experience We had private tour that was worth it. It's 20miles from the city and you will pass the presidents home on the way Also worth noting that this is still used by the locals for recreation and national use for public events not just a museum. I liked that fact as it's still part of Russia today Anyone still deciding if you're going to come to Russia. We totally recommend it. The people are really nice, it's easy for English speaking people and the city's are some of the most beautiful in the world equal to Paris and Venice

Peterhof, recommended for a place to relax and have fun with friends or family, good for children. We took a boat from Saint Petersburg to Peterhof, an early boat to arrive in time for the fountains and opening. We took two tours, one of the Palace and one of the jewels, both impressive but my favorite part of Peterhof was the park, so family friendly and beautifully landscaped. For a relaxing day, I highly recommend spending an entire day here.
Okay but nothing amazing.... Visited this location and got lost finding it then wandered around the gardens and various buildings.

must visit while in petersburg. A wonderful summer palace and a must visit place while in petersburg. The upkeep, beauty and golden statues are breathtaking. Should be visited in summers when fountains are working. Its a different experience altogether. Audio guides are available
Good. Museum is very interesting to visit. Hi-tech equipment is used to let us hear the guide better. But some negative things are high prices and lack of possibility of taking pictures

Amazing . Gilded Summer palace,
This place will not disappoint .
For the best photographs : go on a sunny day.
Tip: wear comfortable walking shoes
Stunning Palace. Although we were there on a cold October day this place is stunning. The fountains and gold statues sparkled and were breathtaking. Inside and out this palace is highly recommended.

Peterhof Church: Peter and Paul Cathedral in Novy Peterhof. The court construction of the Peter and Paul Cathedral in Novy Peterhof was a significant stage in the creative work of Nikolay Vladimirovich Sultanov (1850-1908), based on the theoretical and practical promotion of Russian style in the domestic architecture, one of the main directions, successively developed during the reign of Emperor Alexander III. Among the rare exhibits: the tomb for the shroud is the only remaining objects of decorative art created by project N. V. Sultanov, uvrazh with pictures of the iconostasis, specially made for offerings to the Emperor Alexander III, and expertly executed drawings of Church utensils and tiles.

nothern jewel. Peterhof is home of the first Russian emperor - Peter the Great, and everything in this place reminds of this outstanding personality and his character. All the palaces and the great park show exceptional taste of their first master.Even though it was very cold this summer during our visit, we enjoyed the park, the seasight, the fountains. We would gladly return once again on our own without an excursion.By the way, there are no cafes or restaurants in the park, only small carts with overpriced pancakes, ice-cream and beverages. So I would recommend either to bring snacks with you or to have a proper meal in St. Petersburg.

Fountains and Walkways for Days. Peterhof is an excursion that you shouldn't miss. It's a 30-minute boat ride in each direction to reach Peterhof. Once you arrive, you can wander the grounds as long as you like. I was there for hours and still didn't see everything. This is a nice trip for individuals or families. I went during the summer heat, but there are many shady walking paths under trees. There are also snack stands and souvenir stands all over the place. The history is romantic; the structures are enormous!

Brilliant!. Just one of the most amazing places I have ever visited! The golden statues surrounding the grounds and water fountains are incredible. Hard to believe the Nazi's left this place in ruins. Bucket list must do!
Best place which I liked the most . I wanna visit again this area because it is too big and the walking fountain were awesome I had picture but I will upload later on it was veery nice

Interesting. A great place to see the Romanofs, Russian Royalty, displayed in pictures and where they are laid to rest after being reburied after being killed by the Bolshovics. An interesting museum with the history of this Island displayed and various artifacts belonging to the Romanof family.

Grand Opulence, Home of Catherine the Great and Peter the Great!. How can I describe a place that is beyond description..opulent, stunning in every way..gorgeous furniture, paintings, immaculate rooms, ambience beyond comprehension in today's day and age...perfectly situated on the water, looking towards Finland sits this immaculate building and grounds..solid gold cupolas, huge greenery, trees, landscaping, stunning interiors - Enjoy this step into Russia and the time of the Czars stunning past..Enjoy, Life is short.

Competition with Versailles. Old Peter the great without question succeeded with creating a competitor with Versailles. Fabulous and overwhelming with opulance. Even if the boat is running it relatively easy to get there via metro and bus so bottom line, it's a MUST.

Simply awesome. There are simply too much to see in this place. I visited there in the afternoon and I regret not visiting earlier. The building itself is gorgeous, and it contains lots of art pieces ranging from Chinese ancient paintings, sculptures, Russian paintings to European art pieces. If you have time after visiting the interior of the palace, make sure also visit the upper garden and lower garden (admission fee required for lower garden). The golden sculptures, fountains, and seaside view in upper garden is a must see, and breathtaking. The lower garden is also pretty cool, each building is quite special with different design style, like the Aviaries is designed by French, while the Bathhouse is in Chinese/Japanese style. One reason I like this place so much is the fusion and integration of Eastern and Western arts, it is like visiting several museums in one day. The bad thing though, is the transportation. I took the minibus (I think is #424) and it was not the easiest transportation method I have had, especially if you do not know Russian. Make sure charge your phone, download the offline map so you know where to get off. I ended up walking around an hour to get to Peterhof because I got off in the wrong station. The museum close pretty early as well.Overall, I think it is an amazing place and a must-see place if you travel to St. Petersburg.

must see. special place in the country side of Russia a short metro ride form petersburg. its worth every minute you spend getting here plan on the whole day. perhof its self is a small quite place to get something to eat or have a coffe
Peterhof State Museum. Peterhof is a fantastic city, in my opinion more beautiful then the original Palais of VersaillesVisit the diferent fontain, see the golf of Finland

Gorgeous place to visit during the summertime. Peterhof' park with its famous fountains is an amazing place. I did not meet anyone, who would go there and then regret about it. It will impress each traveler with its power and beauty. Interiors of the Palace are also great, where each corner keeps history of Russian tsars.

Amazing waterfalls and grounds. This complex of palaces, gardens, fountains and waterfalls is one of Russias most famous tourist attractions. We visited in October, sadly the fountains were switched off but the bonus was no crowds, The Great Cascade is beautiful, the gold statues shone in the autumn sunshine, the view from the terrace down the cascade towrds the sea is stunning.It is worth walking down the stairs beside the cascade and following the canal to the Gulf of Finland , we could see St. Petersburg on the horizon.In the summer months a hydrofoil runs from the city to Peterhof.The gardens and grounds are lovely to stroll through,we had the beautiful autumn colours to admire, the leaves made a golden carpet. So much to see - go and explore I am sure you will enjoy !!!

Excellent. Peterhof opened in 1723 one of the favourite residences of Peter I. We took at bus tour from St. Petersburg that took at least 1 hour 10 minutes. This is the best way to see the Palace is with a tour company as they tell you the history and stories behind the buildings. Our tour guide Julia was a small encyclopedia. As you walk towards the building they are painted an impressive yellow and white with the domes being gold. When you see gold it was real gold (or had been). When you walk up the main staircase you are awed by the extravagance. The stairs themselves are short so that when the women who used them could actually walk up them with their heavy dresses. There dresses weighed at least 40 pounds. When you reach the ballroom you need to look at the floor as well as the walls and ceilings. The artistry of the floors is so amazing as well. Every way you turn is just another ah ha moment. You can see why the peasant wanted to overthrow these guys as they had such well and the serfs were barely getting by. After you are finished with the inside opulence you need to walk outdoors to see the Grand Cascade. The cascade and fountains were developed with a gravity-fed water system. All the statues are gold. At 11:30am they turn on the cascade and water rushes down and the fountains turn on to music. Just beautiful. It is so crowded with people seeing this your are better to wait for the people to disperse somewhat to get your pictures or you will only get arms and heads. The cascade goes down a canal to the sea with some bridges across at various sections to walk across and take pictures back up at the Palace. The whole grounds is 100 hectares with approximately 30 buildings and pavilions decorated with 100 sculptures. Walk down one of the many walkways and you will see another great fountain pavilion or garden. Everything is worth a visit. We loved it all.

St. Petersbug, Russia. The ancient Capital Of Russia, formerly Leningrad, is a wonderful city, warm & friendly people..In my limited 2 days, I wanted ,as much ,but YuKathirina of Comtour, who sincerely believes, " KNOWING GOOD ENGLISH" is talking fast, was not able to convey what she wanted to say after 20 mts.
