I am sure ,had I asked her to translate, in Russian, even she would have been baffled.. Finally, she gave the best option, if u r solo, Take Paul , The Veg. Russian Boxer ? ! 896506338818 & his comfy taxi & be your own boss.Going around town, in circles, hermitage , Museum, The statue square & drive to :Peterhof" Fountain capital of the world, is moneys worth.Thou, I have cruised in many rivers, St.Petersburg By Nite,was the brightest moment of the trip.
good to visit. When you visit St. Petersburg, you can't leave without visiting this place. History is very interesting.

Beware of the weather and company, if you take a boat to Peterhof. I took a boat ride to Peterhof to save time. It was wonderful to arrive on a boat. And the garden and main fountains indeed were everything as I had imagined. However, there is no combination tickets for sell for individual palaces on the main entrance, which means if you want to visit anything apart from the garden, you have to queue twice, once for the ticket, and then to queue for the allocated time slot your ticket allows you get in. And on the day of my visit, all the queues for buying tickets and entering were extremely long.At the end of my visit, I went to pier for the boat, and it was getting windy, I was informed that the company from which I bought return tickets, has cancelled the operation due to weather condition, yet, there is another company, still operated with obviously larger boat and more passengers. Although I got my refund, but I can't help wondering the real reason for cancelling is due to the weather, or due to lack of the passengers of the company i was using. So I took the bus back to St. Petersburg, it was easy enough, there is a mini bus services to the metro station, costed like 55 rubles.

Once in a lifetime. Peter the Great's Palace should be on every bucket list. With the entrance from the Gulf of Finland and it's canal flanked by fountain after fountain the view just keeps improving. The Palace grounds are worth a visit by itself. the famous fountains are in every direction. There are features everywhere. One could spend the entire day just admiring the gardens if the beauty of the palace wasn't waiting on the inside as well. I recommend the extra money and using the Hydrofoil boats. It is faster and delivers great views on the Gulf of Finland. It is a royal entrance. The only issue is that foreign guests pay more than there Russian counterparts for entrance.
The word palace is quite correct. The beauty of the gardens , fountains , and interior , just keeps you staring . No picture taking allowed inside :(

Incredible. I went on a day when it was stormy one moment sunny the next, which I hear is typical. It was breathtaking, on a massive scale. Four hours of walking in the gardens, didn't even look inside, but it was totally worth the time. Thoroughly enjoyable and the English audio tour was really great too. Caught the ferry back to the city, which was a rocky ride, but a great way to travel back and very convenient at both ends. Fantastic day out.
A pleasure palace to defy the imagination. The building has been thoroughly restored to its former splendour. It is however the gardens that can give endless hours of great pleasure.
Great!!. You have to see this. As much as anything else, it's amazing what's been done to reconstruct after WWII. This is the world of the czars, when being the czar was a good deal.

An experience to remember.. The boat leaves from opposite The Hermitage and the trip to and from Peterhof is most enjoyable. As soon as you exit the boat you see magnificent vistas of gardens and fountains. Golden statues adorn the approach to the Palace. The Palace is sumptuous to the extreme and one should not miss the beautiful and lavish rooms and decorations. We enjoyed the entire day, including wandering in the superbly maintained parks and gardens.

Interesting. By the time I saw this, I had seen too many palaces so it was just one more..which is sad, because it was also beautiful. I loved the rooms with the paintings of the royal family, it made it all so real. The gardens with the fountains were lovely.

The Russian Versailles . This is truly a historical treasure! More than 100 golden fountains in the huge gardens is just the beginning of this amazing place. The interior of the palace is majestic and full of Russian history. If you are planning your visit here the transportation is a major issue and if available plan a guided tour, the audio guides are too expensive and not that good.

Beautiful and a must visit place!. Peterhof was always on our itenary to visit when we were planning St Petersburg. I have to say the Palace was beautiful with great architecture, paintings. The exterior looked Massive and the interiors were Royal and outstanding. The gardens and fountains are a delight to see. Besides the sea shore with an endless view is peaceful. Traveling in October meant less ppl and it was exactly that.Definitely a must see..

Blown away by this favorite sight in Russia!. I thought it would be just another palace but it was anything but. Stunning on the inside but when we got to the gardens, I felt like my life had changed. I am not a garden person but these gardens with the fountains totally excited me and I fell in love with this place. I couldn't stop taking pictures and sighing! So lovely you could almost forgive them their excess!
Good if you like history. Interesting, but also overwhelming - too much to take in. We were in a group, and had an excellent guide!

Amazing. We took the Hydrofoil from St. Petersburg to Peterhof. That trip was a great part of the whole experience. I find the ticketing in Russia a bit frustrating and confusing. Pay here -- oh, that is just for the grounds. Pay here -- oh that is just for this house. We want to see the back gardens -- oh they are closed. But, that aside, the gardens and fountains are spectacular, and the tour of the castle was fascinating. Since everything has been rebuilt, the statuary gleams with almost too bright gold paint, but it is all so overwhelming and beautiful. One feels that though these rulers were competing with their contemporaries in Budapest, Vienna, Berlin and Paris for grandeur that these Russian palaces were perhaps more comfortable and family oriented. Perhaps because the ruler was often a Tsarina.

St. Petersburg's Versailes. Beautiful gardens, grounds, fountains. Several different buildings converted to museums. Worth seeing. Very interesting. Allow a few hours to cover a lot of territory. A lovely visit!

St. Peterhof an amazing beautiful Summer Palace in Russia. St. Peterhof vicinity is amazingly beautiful, not only this State Museum, but the rest of the Palace. The gold surroundings in their fountain and the rest of the whole St. Peterhof is beyond description. Words cannot describe the beauty of its surrounding and one has to go and witness this summer Palace themselves to graphically see the magical beauty of it. A must see when St. Petersburg.
A MUST SEE. Well worth a quick hydrofoil down the river to Peterhof. The fountains and cascades are stunning but the interior of the palace is mind-blowing.

Another must-see in St. Petersburg. The nicest way to get there is to take the hydrofoil from the center of St. Petersburg - about a 30 minute ride. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes because you will be walking a lot. Try to get there so you witness the official turning on of the fountains - at 11 a.m. This is accompanied by the playing of an anthem, especially composed for Peterhof - very charming. Explore the park, go to the bath house with its so-called Chinese garden. Be sure to take anti-mosquito protection.
Gorgeous A& Gardens. You owe it to yourself to visit this magnificent site while you are in St. Petersburg. The fountains, gardens & architecture are just too fantastic to miss!

Unbelievable place!. The Summer palace and the 150 acres of landscaped gardens is something to behold! Absolutely stunning landscaping and the palace itself is majestic! truly an amazing place to visit on a nice sunny day.

Amazing Location. Fantastic grounds and buildings. The grounds are spectacular, with fountains, statues and formal planting. The buildings are fascinating ( it was surprising to find they were rebuilt after being razed by the Nazis in WWII).

Stunning. The palace is interesting but the grounds, fountains, and gardens are even better. Though the building as it stands today is not original, it has been nicely restored. Beautiful lower gardens with elaborate fountains and well-manicured grounds. The Palace, the grounds, canal, paths, fountains, etc., are every bit worth the trip.

Interesting Palace and Gardens seen in a rush. It was a highly regulated visit tightly organised by staff at Peterhof. Our guide had to walk backwards and talk at rapid speed as we were rushed through the rooms by staff. It was a shame not to be able to enjoy the lavishly furnished rooms at our leisure. Th rooms were in the decor of any other palace of that time in Europe with precious furniture, wallpaper, curtains and paintings. As Peterhof was destroyed during WW II one has to marvel how well everything was restored soon after the war. The cascade fountains are switched on at certain times for visitors to enjoy. We then had a long walk through the gardens and looked at the outbuildings that Peter the Great had erected for various purposes and relaxation with more fountains and well kept flower boarders. It was ashamed that it rained for our second visit to Peterhof as well as on our first one.

Magical!. Our tour guide escorted us to a hydrofoil boat in St. Petersburg, which jettisoned us to this incredible park. We had no idea what a surprise we were about to experience. WOW, it was a sunny, hot day and the fountains just sparkled and the water spraying out looked like diamonds falling on glass.

Versailles on steroids.. This is Versailles on steroids. The fountains have been recently repainted and the gold is magnificent in the sunlight. We didn't go inside the place but the gardens are worth a visit on their own.

Versailles and more. After a short 40minute ride from the Hermitage by hydrofoil, the Peterhof estate is a real show-stopper. The setting on the Gulf of Finland is glorious and, in perfect sunshine, the scores of fountains give the whole palace an amazing energy. This is all the more remarkable when you look at the large photographs in the grounds showing the level of damage during the three year Nazi occupation. The restoration is stunning. The grounds are the chief attraction but the palace has been designed to show off the best of Russian interior design over the years. This has to be in the top three 'must see' destinations in St Petersburg.
Peterhof. We were told that Peter the Great preferred this place the best out of all his summer homes. the gardens are beautiful and the view of the sea is lovely.

Peterhof. Absolutely stunning gardens, a must to visit. With in the park, are lots of smaller museums all with their own entrance fees. I got the Peterhoff express hydrofoil from beside the palace bridge to take me there and back. Great views of both the city and the gulf of Finland. Make sure you pick a day with good weather, and bring comfortable walking shoes...you could spent hours walking through the various gardens.

Breathtaking. Travelled by Hydrofoil from the city to Peterhof as part of our two day tour from our cruise. Stunning what a place . it was a lovely sunny day when we visited so the gardens fountains and buildings were all in their glory from the outside. Our guide was excellent and kept us well informed. the amount of gold plate is amazing and in the sunlight the glistening was dazzling. Inside got even better what a place to visit highly recommended.

Pretty palace garden. It was hot and stuffy in the palace especially when we waited to put on the shoes covers. Very crowded and the lines moved very slowly. I enjoyed the palace garden more. Beautiful water fountains, fresh air, and a huge park to explore.

Expensive Day. Arrived via water early in order to see the fountains turned on. Worth it. While the area is wonderfully rebuilt, I felt like we were nickled and dimed as each area required a separate entrance fee.
Most beautiful gardens. Unbelievable gardens that are well maintained. Be prepared to walk as the gardens are extensive. The nicety is that because it's outdoors, it's not so crowded. Beautiful

the whole town worth a visit. the city of peterhof is so worth a visit. of course there is the versailles of russia to be seen, peterhof grand palace and parks. yet, the rest of the city is as interesting. the alexandria park, the peter and paul cathedral, the olgin and tsaritsin pavillons, sergievka estate, znamenka estate, ..... taking the boat from hermitage to peterhof is wonderful. but arriving by train is nice, too. the train station 'novy petergof' is an old building by architect benois. and along the town there are so many beautiful buildings.

Photos do not do the Grand Cascade justice. We visited the park and gardens where there are 150 fountains, most of which are natural and don't use pumps. The star of the show is the Samson fountain and Grand cascade which is incredible in its beauty and its perfect proportions and symmetry. I have seen this on photos but in real life it is 100 times better. Apart from the Grand Cascade there are several other fountains to visit, each of them different, including trick fountains which start when someone walks by. You can spend several hours wandering around and admiring the plants and vistas. There are plenty of places selling food and drink and souvenirs.

Spectacular. This was one of the most beautiful places I have ever visited. The grounds are simply stunning. This is a real triumph of outdoor design. I very much enjoyed just walking around and seeing all the fountains. Words cannot describe how beautiful this place is. The surprise fountains are a real treat.

Wonderful history incredibly preserved. Spending a morning at the Peterhof in August was absolutely stunning. For a start the weather was idyllic! (a rare occurrence in St Petersburg!) Although the tours are very strictly regulated and supervised (leading to very little freedom to look at the palace at a leisurely pace) they are well run. Stern middle aged Russian women on every door watch to ensure you do not touch or take photographs inside the palace and can seem a little over zealous at their task, but the result is a very informative and pleasant tour. The rooms are impeccably preserved and wonderfully maintained. You cannot take a bag that is larger than a small handbag so be prepared to check your bags at the reception. Booties also need to be worn inside and they will be provided for you to place over your shoes. Bathroom breaks are available at the start and finish of the house tour and its advisable to use them! It can be a long day!There is a restaurant for more relaxed dining near the entrance and light refreshments are available for purchase as you walk around the gardens. CASH POINTS/ATMs can be found near the main entrance too... worth having a little cash for drinks and a nibble as you wander the vast gardens!The gardens are simply stunning. If you want to wander through at a leisurely pace here you are able too. The information available is plentiful but not forced upon you. One could spend hours just meandering through the acres of land and happening upon historic houses laden with history. Well worth the price! I came on a cruise ship so paid for the tour as part of a larger excursion to the Hermitage also. It took barely 45 minutes to reach the Peterhof from the small cruise terminal in the centre of the city. TOP TIP: Make sure to watch the fountains start at 11am. Get yourself a good spot on the bandstand at about 10:30am for a panoramic view!

The best. If you only visit one place in St petersburg this should be it... spend the day... get there early before 11 for the ceremony of the the fountains. .. if you're lucky enough ..like we were last year.. the closing ceremony in sept is a mind boggling experience like no other
Overwhelming. The palace grounds are spectacular. The amount of gold guiding is beyond impressive. The numerous gravity-fed fountains are great. The parklands are immaculate.

Fantastic outdoor fountains in gardens. Peterhof, built as the summer residence of Peter the Great and his successors is a Royal residence but most of the attraction are the gardens containing many different fountains, a waterfall and statue of Hercules and a canal leading to the Gulf of Finland. Among others, there were separate statues of Adam and Eve, also set in a water fountain. Peterhof is about a 40 minute drive from St.Petersburg center but is definitely worth it. In good weather one can take a hydrofoil via the Gulf of Finland to get there.

Place to visit. Peterhof was founded By Peter The Great and it is one of the most beautiful places in Europe.Peterhof contains Great Palace, Great Cascade, Upper Garden, Lower Park, Colonists' Park, Alexandria Park, Konstantinovsky Palace, Palaces and Parks of Oranienbaum. My favorite places in Peterhof are Great Cascade and Lower Park. Especially I like Trick fountains in Lower Park. This 18th century fountains was founded by Peter The Great and they still are working and most amusement place in all park.The Great Palace and park complex occupies an area of 1000 hectares. The Great Cascade contains 60 fountains and 250 statues. This very beautiful, sparkling golden complex is breathtaking. There are fountains, cascades, water pools, gardens, statues, flowers in the Lower Park. The best way to reach Peterhof is by Meteor cater by Neva river. They go regularly and it takes just 30 minutes from Saint-Petersburg to Peterhof by Meteor (Because the bad traffic on the roads it can take many hours by car or coach). Round tickets for Meteor costed for us 1200 rubles for adult and entrance ticket to Lower garden was 500 rubles for an adult. Peterhof is great place to visit for everyone.

Worth the visit!. I arrived before the attraction was even open and it was wonderful to beat the expanding crowds. Again the guide was essential. The group was moved through the rooms at a pace not too rushed but quickly enough not to be overrun with people. The grounds and fountains are really lovely.

Gardens are Spectacular. We specifically went to Peterhof to see the gardens and we were not disappointed - they were awesome and quite an architectural achievement. The fountains were beautiful with lots of nice places to stop and photograph and enjoy. Then just strolling through the grounds and seeing all the gravity fed fountains and waterfalls was very enjoyable. A bit of walking with some hills but worth the minor exertion. We were not able to go inside the palace but we were not disappointed but just being able to see the fabulous grounds all around this museum.

Beautiful Palace but packed with people. This is a very beautiful restored palace. It was destroyed during WWII. The walls of many rooms are covered with gold leaf and period paintings . The inlaid floors are also beautiful . The exterior garden is arranged in terraces with gold leaf sculptures down to the Baltic Sea where you can return to St Petersburg via hydrofoil. The palace and grounds are packed with people in August. Worth seeing but be prepared for crowds.

OTT. This place really is Over The Top, with all the gold leaf and ostentatious living. It's interesting to see but I really enjoyed the gardens best. What a lovely way to spend some hours.
It's a splendid facade and the fountains magnificent.

Beautiful Palace restored with great and Beautiful detail.. Some of the best Palace rooms in existence. Totally rebuild after it was destroyed by the Nazi in WWII. The rooms are breath taking. The wood inlaid floors are the best we have seen.
Great Building.

Royal Splendor.. As part of a recent cruise from St Petersburg to Moscow, we opted for a 1/2 day trip to Peterhof. The house is very impressive but the fountain display is incredible to see and a wonder of engineering. The view from the patio goes to the Baltic Sea. It would be a little difficult for wheelchairs but not impossible. Must go in the morning to see the fountains.

Peterhof Palace and Gardens. This place is also called sometimes the Russian Versailles.The park hold numerous fountains and also a few monumental cascades which makes it interesting attractions.Grand Palace entrance by ornate Ceremonial Staircase is pretty good to watch!

Incredible. If you have an interest in hydraulic engineering it will make your jaw drop. Hundreds of fountains and not a pump in use...and designed in the early 18th C. If you do not, it is just the most beautiful Palace. Peter the Great's summer palace. 40 mins by Hydrofoil from St Perersburg. Breathtakingly magnificent. Destroyed in WW2 by bombing and wilful sabotage but rebuilt starting in 1946.

One of the highlights!. Even though Peterhof is a 30 min drive away it's certainly worth the trip. We took an UberX (1.000rub) and got out at the ticket shop. We strolled through the forest like gardens on the sea side. Looked out over the east-sea and, above all, admired the cascade with its beautiful golden statues and stunning layout. The palace serving as the perfect backdrop. We took the boat back to SPB, but to be honest, this was a underwhelming experience. The staff is rude, the interior run down and the smell of gasoline stays with you for hours after.
One of the most beautiful places I've ever been. Take a private tour as they can cut the lines and show you the important parts. Worth the investment

Unbelievable. Wonderful, you cannot believe how amazing this place is, it's so opulent. It should be one of the wonders of the modern world. The fountains are spectacular, the gold statues are amazing and we got drenched in some of the fun fountains. It was a memorable day well worth a visit. Just unbelievable.
Beautiful gardens and walks. The state museum is nice but be sure to visit the gardens adjacent to the museum and stroll the fountains and gardens. Its also a nice view onto the sea.

The Most Amazing Palsce. The biggest Museum I have seen. Amazing collections of pairings very real and a very detaile history of how Peter The Great loved how smart he was, very diplomatic to conquer a he wanted. Great history description of the real life lived than! We just had a glance because in order to be able to see every exposition of the Palace would take years by only spend 3 minutes looking at every exposition. Amazing and hard to keep everything in pus mind.great history ! Endless, almost impossible to explain so much beauty and history.

Wow! Stunning!. Visited Peterhof as a small group! The buildings are beautiful, but the gardens with their vast amount of stunning fountains and gold statues are the best! We arrived at 11am just as they were turning on all the fountains with classical music playing. Amazing sight! The gardens were vast, and all the small pathways led to a different fountain! Lots of shade for hot days and places to sit! A must visit place!

Stay ahead of the crowds to enjoy the gardens and fountains in peace!. We visited the Lower Fountain Park at Peterhof in August. In good weather the palace is in a glorious setting on the Gulf of Finland. We arrived shortly before 1100 when the big fountain display starts. Due to the huge crowd waiting for 1100 we wandered around the park first enjoying the beautifully maintained gardens and the variety of fountains. We managed to be a step ahead of the crowds for the large part of our visit. My son enjoyed the trick fountains although we saw a few people get rather wet!We visited with a guide and were therefore able to appreciate the history of the park and the palace and also understand how some of the fountains survived WW2. We returned to the main fountains as our visit neared an end and whilst still crowded they were not as busy as when we arrived.We didn't go inside the palace but the gardens and fountains are well worth a visit in their own right. Spare around two hours + for a visit.

Peter the Great Had it Good. The palace is interesting but the grounds, fountains, and gardens are even better. Lovely shaded pathways lead the visitor from one beautiful vista to yet another. Benches are located throughout the grounds so that you can rest your weary feet. The site abuts the Gulf of Finland which provides cooling breezes. A special fountain show is scheduled at 1100 hours. This fountain is just below the rear of the palace.One of the most enjoyable palace sites in St. Petersburg, particularly the grounds and gardens.

Beautiful, if not original. Vacation villa built by Peter the Great. The 30-room palace was bombed by the Soviets during WWII. Though the building as it stands today is not original, it has been nicely restored. Beautiful lower gardens with elaborate fountains and well-manicured grounds.  You could spend hours strolling the grounds.  Arrive on the 10:00 am hydrofoil and head straight to the palace to beat the tourist hordes.

fabulous. This amazing building can be approached via a hydrofoil from the centre of town. The fountains are plentiful and the gardens immense. As with other places you need to watch out for pick pockets.

Beautiful gardens and fountains at the home of Peter the Great!. We visited Peterhof, the home of Peter the Great, with Nina Kazarina,our guide from SPB Tours, and found it to be a welcome outdoors visit of beautiful gardens and gilded cascade fountains. Our 2 teenage children enjoyed walking around the grounds and participating in the "trick" fountains! This was an eye-opener to the wealth and extravagance of the tsars. Nina K. made it an enjoyable visit and gave us much history of the site...a thoroughly enjoyable respite where you can stretch your legs and wander around amid the history of the Russian aristocracy. I recommend SPB tours which included this visit in our 2-day Deluxe Private Tour of St. Petersburg and made all of our tramsportation and entry into all other locations so easy and enjoyable as well.

Marvelous Cascade of Fountains. I don't even know if I have words that can adequately describe how gorgeous and exquisite the Peterhof gardens are. I was blown away!Fountains, flowers and statues everywhere - every inch a feast for the eyes. A MUST SEE!TIP: Allow at least 2 hours to view the gardens.

Just stunning. We only went around the grounds but you get a really good feel for the place. Highlights include the 11am fountain display to music (be prepared to be jossled), the gold leaf and the walk through the woods down to the waterfront. Well worth a visit!!

Fantastic gardens and fountains. Less impressive interior. This is 45-50 minutes from downtown. The gardens and fountains here are absolutely breathtaking and I'm told are the closest thing to Versailles. Please note that fountains are closed and drained in the fall and not opened again until spring. When I was there, it was separate charge to tour inside. The collection here is simply drawfed by the one in the downtown palace.

Not to be missed.. I had heard a lot about this place,but words can't say the utter truth.This is a place of unique beauty,with great,beautiful and very clean parks to walk around.The fountains are also great.

Peterhoff is WELL worth the hydrofoil trip!. Overwhelming at times as there is SO much to see on the grounds. The Palace, the grounds, canal, paths, fountains, etc., are every bit worth the trip. However, please allot enough time to not be rushed. It was especially beautiful for us since the weather was so nice when we went there in June. I can imagine the attractiveness of the grounds themselves might decrease a touch when the weather is not as pleasant. We may have just gotten lucky! Enjoy!

Too touristic!. We visited by boat the state and the trip back and forth was nice. But on the site there were too many people, thousands of tourists. Probably just a bad timing but it was really annoying. We walked without a guide, there were not many signs or descriptions. The place itself is very magnificent and I have to come back in low season.

We walked quickly to the fountains to see them with music playing. We went by boat with TJ Travel and the view gradually came into sight. We arrived just in time for the display playing to music , appatentky only twice a day, and even though it rained we didn't mind. Gardens were lovely too, chequerboard fountain a bit different.

Beautiful grounds and fountains. We were lucky to have amazing weather the morning we visited Peterhof. We didn't go into the Museum, but spent our time on the grounds and they were just amazing. You could spend quite some time here and there are tons of photo stops. We decided to spend time in the other palaces in St. Petersburg, so the interior didn't make the list, with only 3 days in port here. The exterior is quite beautiful and be sure to take the hydrofoil, as it is a great way to see the view in yet another way as you arrive.

Before Las Vegas and Dubai , Peterhof. The place is immense. A tour could eat up your entire day. The fountains are spectacular. Ok, KL, Dubai and Las Vegas are better but these are hundreds of years old. All of us enjoyed watching the fountains. The building was nice to tour. I highly recommend a guide so that you know what you are looking at. Spend some time in the trick fountain area.

Beautiful preserve that is a must for all tourists to St Petersburg. Stunning gardens, beautiful buildings, exquisite gold colored statues in the front of the palace. Up to the standard of the Palace of Versaille and gardens in France. Well worth the hydrofoil trip ftom St Petersburg to spend a couple of hours wandering around the grounds of Peterhof. A must for tourists visiting St Petersburg.

Breathtaking Palace, Gardens, & Fountains!. Peterhof is probably the most beautiful place I have ever been to!! It is one of the palaces of Peter the Great built in 1710s - 1720s, and is rightfully called "Russian Versailles." The architecture is simply stunning: It has elements of the Renaissance, Baroque, and Classicism. The most incredible are the fountains (there are so many of them): Grand Cascade, Samson Fountain, Chess Mountain Cascade, Roman Fountains, Adam and Eve Fountains - just to name a few! Peterhof is a MUST-SEE place to visit!

Beautiful!. Another beautiful palace of the Tzars. Gorgeous inside and out. The main fountains are turned on at 11 am so try to be in the gardens for that event. The gardens and parks are extensive but worth a stroll down to the Baltic.

Unreal decadence. After a short boat ride to this amazing place I was completely setback by the amount of fountains on the property. The gardens and grounds were immaculate. The palace was impeccably manicured inside and out. Be prepared for alot of walking. We were on a professional tour and still spent 4 hours at this incredible destination.
Stunning and evocative. The grounds are amazing before you even step across the entrance into the building. Amazing and stunning interiors of a yet another display of grandeur and wealth

A lovely walk in the gardens after a long day of touring.. It was great to step out of the heart of St. Petersburg and enjoy a few hours wanering the beautiful palace and amazing gardens. The fountains are just spectacular. I must admit that wandering the gardens was my favorite part of visiting St. Petersburg.

GREAT PLACE ...Go by the Hydro foil boat service!!!. A great place to go ...budget at least 3.5 to 4 hrs to do justice...sply if with family / kids. Remember that there are speed hydrofoil shuttle services from near Admiratiskaya boat pts tp Peterhff and back...You will beat the road travel and enjoy the scenic ride in the waterways...We got to know of it only after reaching the Museum
Russain Versailles. Beautiful gardens with original fountains. The Russian Versailles. accessed buy road or hydrofoil (a fun ride).

Beautiful place to visit.. Be sure to visit this place. Lovely garden with amazing Fountains. A MUST see. Don't miss it. Take public transport or the boat from St. Petersburg. Buy the post cards if you don't take photos.

A must do in St Petersburg. The gardens and fountains are amazing. We actually gave the palace a miss after seeing several in St Petersburg already but just visited to see the lower gardens and fountains - and were not disappointed.We caught the bus (a mini-van/bus) from Avtovo Metro Station - very easy, there are several on the side of the road with Peterhof or Петергоф written on the side - and cost 40RUB per person one way (takes about 15/20 mins). The van drops you at the entrance to the upper gardens (which are free) and then you walk through them to get a ticket to the lower gardens, where the fountains are. The lower gardens are huge and you can spend minimum an hour wandering around. We went late in the day and were going to catch the boat back to St Petersburg however at that time of day, the wait for the next boat with a seat on it was almost 2 hours. So we walked all the way back to the road and caught the bus back, plenty of them on the road heading back to Avtovo Metro (and they are 10 times cheaper).So just a tip regarding the boat: there are a couple of different boat operators, not all of them take credit cards, so you'll need cash, and be prepared to wait if there are a lot of people around!But even if you just catch the bus there and back, it's well worth it - and you'll save some more money for beers/vodka later :-)

Beautiful palace and gardens. Peterhof is a beautiful place to spend most of a day if you have time. But you can manage it in half a day if you buy tickets early online. Getting there early will help to avoid the crowd.The palace itself is beautiful and the gardens and fountains are amazining. You can get to Peterhof by boat from Hermitage in 40 minutes or by road.

Go for the Gardens, Be Amazed by the Fountains. By far, my favorite excursion in St. Petersburg! The Palace is beautiful, but the highlights are the gardens and the fountains. With much pomp and circumstance, the fountains turn on at 11am and you just marvel with awe! The gardens have all sorts of statues and fountains and you can walk right out to the Baltic Sea. Spend your time outside and walk extensively through the gardens. Again, lots of steps and not very handicap friendly.

Use the boat from St. Petersburg to get here.. Great place for a walk. Nice gardens and palace. Even if you´re not a history lover, you can have nice time just walking through, no need to visit the museum. The gardens are open every day, entrance fee is 500 Rub. It has two entrances, the one that is from the sea is less busy. You can take a fast boat from Hermitage in St. Petersburg. They leave every 30 minutes and the ride is about 30 minutes too. Its cheaper to buy a return ticket, one way cost us 700 Rub per person. It was an easy and entertaining way to get there. The boat leaves you at the beach right at Peterhof.
Spectacular!. The fountains and the gardens are not to be missed when in St. Petersburg. Definitely a showcase to rival Versailles!

Spectacular . Absolutely worth seeing the impressive palace and the fountains. A tour company arranged transportation and a guide for my family. We came away very impressed. The palace tour requires special shoe covers which can make the floor seem slippery. No strollers allowed inside the palace. The grounds and fountains were incredible.

OPULENT FOUNTAINS, VERY BUSY PARK. Peterhof may be reached from Avtovo metro by marshrutka. Just ask the driver for "the fountains". Even though English is not spoken, you'll get there easily.This is absolutely overrun with tourists. After seeing the park and wandering around, you can return by hydrofoil which gives you a separate experience.However, if I were to rate this, I'd say, go to Oranienbaum instead.

The beautiful garden. Peterhof is a amazingly beautiful place. I enjoyed the fountains and the gardens. This is another very popular place in St. Petersburg. I highly recommend to anyone who plans to visit St. Petersburg.

Well.. Just the fountains outside will leave you speechless. Don't think I need to say more. The park grounds and fountains alone are worth the visit (which is pretty much what we did). Believe you can't go in.

Wow,what a place!. For me, this was the top attraction during our two day visit. The buildings, fountains, and grounds were all outstanding. Definitely worth spending adequate time to see the entire site.

Unbelievable visit to Peterhof. There is so much to see in this state that was the rest house for Peter the Great. Gardens are fantastic, the palace is impressive, the tens of sculptures are also beautiful, there are also several fountains. If you visit St. Petesburg a trip to Peterhof is mandatory, you'll enjoy it.

Top attraction - Peterhof. Peterhof and its gardens are definitely the top attraction of the city. Our tour group had early, pre-opening access - huge queues waiting to enter as we were leaving. The interior is quite amazing to view; the fountains, gardens and statues provide yet further enjoyment. Try to time your visit early in the day.

Stunning & Unbelievable Beautiful. Although we did not get to see the palace from inside, the building itself is stunning beautiful. The cascading fountains with statues are truly amazing. The luxurious garden s around the palace with lake a very very pleasant walk. An amazing place for shutter bugs. Weather is unpredictable though. Rain jackets/umbrellas highly recommended. If one can afford must spend one full day at this place.

Booking a tour could be wiser. Being around 45min away from the city by boat, the island is beautiful and probably one of the most beautiful garden palaces around Europe!If you are going to visit the palace inside...For non Russian speakers I'd just like to give you all a heads up, that if you go by yourself (As in not with a tour) to the main palace, you will have to stick with a group since you're not really allowed to stroll around by your own. That being said, most of the visitors are locals, most of the people in your group will be locals, which means that the guide who leads groups will be explaining EVERYTHING in Russian. The whole tour is around 60-90min if I remember correctly and once again you're not really allowed to leave the group so it will be quite "less interesting" if you are keen to know about the stories behind. So, my suggestions is either you are going to not understand what's happening around you and simply enjoy the beautiful palace with a group of Russians, or you'd better book a English speaking tour to enjoy the whole experience.
The beautiful fountains. The fountains at the Peterhof is a site to be seen. This was my favorite tourist attraction in St. Petersburg.

If you like palaces and gardens.. We were there early in the morning since we specifically asked our tour operator to get us early entrance tickets. That kind of ticket allows you to get in before the official opening hour, but I do not think you can get those if you buy your tickets yourself. However this is a must if you do not want to be stuck in a big crowd and it will allow you to see a lot more in a lot less time, allowing you to see more of the other wonders of St.Petersburg.Many call this place the "Russian Versailles". In fact if you already visited Versailles you will find that the comparison might be good about the gardens, but the Perterhof Palace cannot really be compared with the Versailles Palace. Peterhof is quite small in comparison. Yes it is still a pretty big place, but nothing to compare to Versailles.The gardens are really beautiful and the stories related to the different alleys are interesting. (Ask about the tricky fountains!) And it is fun to see that the main fountains are still turn on manually (around 11h) just in front of the Palace.The Palace is interesting but you can see most of it within an hour.If you never saw Versailles I definitely recommend Peterhof. But if you did see Versailles I would still recommend to see Peterhof, but do not have to many expectation. Go for the history, not the Palace.

A great outing. Peterhof is an impressive location that ought to be included in a visit to Saint Petersburg, but maybe not in the Winter, as its principal offering are the great gardens.
We got a boat from the center of StPB out to Peterhof, which added an extra experience.

Beautiful !. Keep a full day for this excursion if you truly wish to experience the place properly - the place is beautiful with fountains, lush green gardens, - something to really transform you to a blissful state, if you happen to walk hand in hand with your loved one.From St. Petersburg, one can take a speed-boat option(highly recommended but if weather is rough, it may not operate), cab or bus - also, eating joints inside the premises are overpriced but if you wish to venture outside for a bite or sight-seeing, one will have to an entry ticket again - a big irritant if you have to take a speed boat back to St. Petersburg - if you opt to take a cab/bus back - by all means to venture out too.

A must for visitors to St. Petersburg. The spectacle of the Grand Cascade, with its gilded statues and fountains, is hard to describe. The fountains turn on at 11:00 a.m., and the crowds gather well before that to see them and hear the accompanying music. It is an experience not to be missed. The interior of the palace is also impressive, of course, but it is hard to match the display outside. Although what the visitor sees is a reconstruction of the 18th century structures and grounds, destroyed by the Germans who occupied them in World War II, the beauty of the place is truly astounding.We toured with TJ Travel while on a cruise, which made for easy admission to the palace and a great English language guided tour.

Stunningly beautiful Peterhof grounds. Absolutely breathtaking. Stunning golden statues and fountains everywhere. Yes a lot of walking involved but most of it is on the flat. Well worth it. Beautiful.Tip: Food just outside the entrance over priced. Go down the road opposite them for 50yards for a much cheaper cafe with good food and drinks. Great place to visit!!!!

Worth the trip outside the city. Another beautiful castle with lovely gardens filled with private gardens and trick water gardens that will get you wet if you step on the correct stones to set off the fountains. The castle itself is well maintained and very beautiful. Definitely worth the trip outside the city to view it.

This is the Russian Versailles. This is a large complex and has lots of areas to visit and reminds me of Versailles, France. There are cafe's and restaurants, we ate at an open air restaurant and had a great time.

Just amazing. What a perfect place to spend a few hours. We were lucky to pick a lovely sunny day as the gardens are just fantastic. The cascading fountains look even more impressive than the photos in the holiday magazines and the rest of the garden is almost as impressive. The Palace itself is stunning with many rooms to explore. Finish it off by taking the Hydrofoil back to St Petersburg,

Unbelievable!. Just breathtaking. We were lucky to be there when gardens in full bloom...probably in summer there are other flowers but early June so much in bloom. The fountains are spectacular... and the gilding on the statues is so fresh. It will certainly take your breath away!

"A Grand Excursion". Your reward for a visit to Peterhof is a magnificent czarist palace. However, the grounds alone are worth the trip, especially the dazzling fountain display and the magic water sprinklers. You can easily imagine yourself as a royal guest enjoying all of the privileges of the old Russian aristocracy.
excellent. I think this must be one of the most beautiful places I have ever been to. We went by hydrofoil and it was a lovely journey and only took 40min

WOW!!!. Peterhof is a must see in St. Petersburg. The fountains and grounds are spectacular. Make sure you're there before 11am so you see the daily show at 11am where the main fountains are turned on and music played...what a show!

Gardens and Palaces galore. The detail and impressive size of the Peterhof was incredible, with so much history, a visual feast to the eyes and the grand scale is impressive with a huge coverage of art work and history of the palace in one with Gardens and woodlands, exceptional

Personal favorite! The fountains!. Loved it! Go when fountains are on, May-October. We went there by hydrofoil on the Neva River and into Gulf of Finland. You can go under the fountains in front and see the old wood pipes and the trick fountains of Peter the Great. Around the grounds don't miss Adam fountain, chess board fountain, and Roman fountains. The inside rooms are impressive too, but the fountains fascinated me!

St. Petersburg at its best. We loved our quick trip to St. Petersburg on a return from a week in Ukraine. It is a gorgeous city, much more Western European than Western. The Peterhof was a great stop that we enjoyed very much. We visited when the sun did not set and took full advantage to see as much as possible with a friend guiding us through.
Breathtaking, relaxing and fun!. Absolutely beautiful! The water features were fun for kids of all ages. It was very helpful to have a guide!

Beautiful and touristic. One cannot deny that Peterhof is beautiful. The fountain in front of the great palace is among the most impressive I've had the chance to see. The great palace itself, full of golden adornments at the walls, is just gorgeous. The park and gardens are also amazing! However, it is far from Saint Petersburg and everything is expensive after passing the gates. Just be prepared for it.

World class - worth the time. Excellent restoration, still underway. Spectacular building, and while the interior art and rooms are impressive, the gardens and the fountains are possibly the greater attraction ( on a nice day) The place turns into an anthill and recommend getting an early private interior tour.

Fantastic Fountains on display. Came and left by Hydrofoil from opposite the Hermitage to pier at bottom of the Peterhof palace gardens. Great way to travel and see the River Neva join the Gulf of Finland. There is a service every 15min and ticket return 900rblsPeterhof gardens are all about the fountains. Covered in gold leaf they make a spectacular sight. Do walk around the gardens as there will be, in addition to the central display, one -off fountains in different styles dotted around the gardens.Only disappointment was trying to get into the palace. Priority for Russians only tourists after 3pm maybe. Communicated by a red faced angry guard in full uniform making himself very clear despite not speaking a word of English. Why spoil such a treasure with such ham fisted interaction with tourists.

Peterhof the Great. Their is so much history in St Petersburg and the Tsar's and their excesses have left us with amazing reminders. You could spend hours just here wandering the gardens, let alone gasping as you go from room to room inside the palace. When the fountains come on at 11 it is indeed amazing despite the hordes of tourists around every vantage point. Do read up or get a guide so you get the most from the experience because the history behind it all is amazing.

Absolutely great, just like the Peter the Great!. A must visit. We took a boat to the preserve and a bus back. Get there at the right time to experience the daily lighting of the fountains with accompanying music.

"Bright and green". This place unites the desire of eye for green and wild 'divine engineering' framed by the man into his own 'standard of the beautiful' (just cannot explain otherwise why one tends to come back :) Everything is here: the masses of water raising up and falling down in tens of thousands of tones per minute, the wide of the open sea, the green of both cared and uncared nature, the ducks and pigeons asking for and cheating out of snacks… sculpture, palaces, gold and marble… the history… the tourists with cameras, the ice cream… great time, great fun!

The grounds, gardens and fountains, were stunning. While I did enjoy my visit, I was disappointed that due to the crowds midday I could not obtain admission to the palace. The gardens and fountains are absolutely beautiful, and there were plenty of them to see.

Emperial Glory and problematic entry to the Palace. great to spend a day at. Great photo op's by fountains and in the park. Couldn't get into the palace two visits in a row: no access for two or three hours in the middle of the day. Still a long (familiar for a former citizen) line to get into the palace. Tried to negotiate access to cash registers for a "foreign fee' to let my daughter and her boyfriend go, and got laughed at (after a quick profiling- welcome to the Soviet Union of the 70's). Got disgusted and left the premises.a fee to enter the park (different pricing for Russians and foreigners), a far away bathroom, and according to my daughter, on a dirty side.Just know what not to expect service-wise.

an improved copy of Versailles palace. the pallace is great, with all treasures of art, jewlwry, porcelain, etc. But the real thing is he garden with those fountains that operate without pumps, receiving their water from a distance of 22 km. The fact that a large part of the tubing is the original pipeline is amazing, indicating the huge engineering effort that was put into this place. The beauty cannot be described in words. you have to be there to understand. going back to the city via hydrofoil is a very nice experience as well.

Awesome rooms and gardens. The Summer Palace is set in extensive grounds of manicured fountain gardens. We had to wear disposable booties over our footwear as we entered the palace and were repeatedly reminded that no photography is allowed within the palace. With all this preparation, the anticipation was high. We were not disappointed! Absolutely sumptuously restored rooms in all their magnificent glory amazed us. We understood the need for the booties that protect the carefully designed parquet floors. Before we headed out to the gardens, we made a stop in the Gift Shop that has a very wide selection of souvenirs and the best Amber jewellery collection that I had seen thus far. The prices were reasonable. The Gardens were beautiful with something for everyone - sculptures, numerous fountains, roses and other flowers, trees and manicured hedges. Take the walk to the residence facing the Gulf of Finland and soak in the coastline view. Before leaving, rub your hand on the feet of the statue there to be blessed with health and wealth! The feet of this sculpture are shining from the thousands of hands that have rubbed against it. There are small cafes in the gardens but make sure you have rubles! An ice cream in hand would have perfected our enjoyment of the gardens but we had to be disappointed since they refused Visa or euros or US Dollars. Peterhof gets my vote for the most spectacular attraction in St Petersburg. Must not miss this and definitely worth the 22 mile drive to it.

Absolutely beautiful gardens. We arrived by hydrofoil and walking up toward the Peterhof Museum was breathtaking. We were not visiting the Palace itself as time didn't allow but we had time to explore the gardens, all the different fountains, including the trick ones and to take many pictures of this beautiful place. When leaving St. Petersburg on a sunny evening on our cruise ship we were able to see this place, with the aid of binoculars, from our balcony.
Place to visit. Definitle You should get there.Beauty and magic of this summer palace and gardens complex breathtaking!Вне сомнений стоит побывать там.Красота и магия этого комплекса захватывает дух!

FUN!. We visited the Peterhof gardens and had great fun watching kids play in the 'surprise' fountains. The long walk around the gardens was a joy. Some of the gardens were quite formal while others were casual. The facade of the Peterhof was luxurious and fun. The fountains throughout the gardens were wonderful.. Don't miss it.
Peterhof Fountains and Gardens. Mind-boggling and breathtaking. What a genius to be able to keep all those fountains flowing without a pump!! So beautiful!
Fountains galore. Exploring the acres of fountains was a delight even for us old folks. I got wet at as many fountains as I could - I guess there is a child in all of us - even Peter the Great.

A need see. The Peterhof was one of the places that we could not see from the inside we seen the building from outside and part of the garden that Catherine The Great would walk around and it had hardly changed from then

Strange place. This place is a vast palace with a lot of big hall and a lot of beautiful fountain. There is a 500 rubles as an entrance fee.if u wanna see that u gotta make itself ready to spend 5 hours minimum.
There is a special macket museum next to the entrance door.i suggest that .

Must do!. It's worth the time/effort/expense to tour these grounds as they were built based upon the Palace of Versailles. It's immense and awe-inspiring and I'm sure you'll quite enjoy the exterior grounds more than the crowded, packed interior!Don't miss the Dog chasing Ducks fountain and watch out for the trick fountains. When I scheduled the tour, I combined it with Catherine's Palace and selectively chose to only tour the grounds here while touring the interior of Catherine's Palace for the famed Amber Room and grounds. I wanted to avoid the crowds, see both sites in one trip outside of St. Petersburg and kept in mind the attention span of my 7 year old!

A Historic Gem in St. Petersburg. Guided tours were welcome and the artifacts are as genuine as the pride our tour guide had in Russian history. It is a smaller version of the French Versailles, yet elegant and beautiful at the same time. The fountains and light show we witnessed a the end of the night was special. The fountains flow to the Baltic Sea and the view from the veranda to the Baltic makes for a romantic photo op. If you visit St. Petersburg, this venue offers a historical look at one of Russia's finest gems.

Make sure you go during opening hours for foreigners. This was a bit of a disappointed as there are only certain hours for foreigners, so make sure you time your visit correctly or you will be waiting a lot of time. Its worth it, but only if you have time in the city.

Overcrowded, but a must!. It is easy to understand the revolutions in 1917! What a beautifull palace! The fountains start to flow at 11AM. It was overcrowded and tourist are not very pleasant to each other. You will have to check your coat and bags, a horrible ordeal. The gardens are to die for and the waterfront chalets cute. We retuned to the city via hydrofoil a 40 minute ride.

Make sure to be there when the fountains are running. The Nazi's completely destroyed this amazing palace, but its been magnificently restored. the hydrofoil runs between the Peterhof and Winter Palace in St Petersburg. its a must do experience (and its very convenient).

Spectacular Gardens. We arrived by hydrofoil & walked upwards towards palace. Fountains start at 11 am & is worth seeing the start up -they are all gravity fed. Funny trick fountains are dispersed throughout gardens that make it quite fun for the young & young at heart. We spent so much time in the gardens- if weather good a photographer's dream.

A must see Palace. The Palace build for Peter the Great is well preserved. You do tend to be "encouraged" to move through the museum at a steady pace and not given much opportunity to linger in each of the rooms. But there is still time to view the rooms and gain a sense of how he and his family lived. The Fountains and Gardens around the Palace are a must see. Here you can take your time a enjoy. The fountains start at 11:00 am and it is certainly worth being there before this time to see he start up.

The Gardens are Spectacular. I made a conscious choice to not tour the palace but to simply visit the gardens. Having already seen Versailles and spent two days in the Hermitage, I wanted to see what made this palace particularly unique. It was definitely the gardens! In addition to the jaw-dropping gold statues of the main cascade, give yourself plenty of time to find treasure through the garden paths.All of the grandeur and gold can certainly indicate why anyone would want to have a revolution. It was definitely beyond "let them eat cake." I am really grateful that they had a great exhibit in the upper gardens showing how the working class felt about the palace and toured the palacial rooms, post-revolution.It was also touching to see displays that showed so much of the palace bombed out and how much work they have done to restore it to its original splendour.While many people pay lots of extra money to take the hydrofoil over, I really enjoyed maneuvering the Metro and the maroushka van. Very reasonably priced and they drop you off directly in front of the upper garden.

Gardens. By the time we visited here we were overwhelmed with palaces and art so we only wandered the gardens. They were fabulous. The fountains throughout the grounds were amazing. They had photos of what had been left of the palace after the siege of Leningrad and it wasn't much; basically exterior walls. The reconstruction and renovation were beautifully done (even if seen only from the outside). A must see!
Good Palace. If you have been to Versailles you will see how they tried to copy. While not nearly as splendid, it is worth the visit.

Still Soviet era service. We went for the day. The only thing that let us down was a total lack of planning and organisation of the palace. The staff were uniformly rude and unhelpful. No assistance for non Russian speakers. Just another palace.

A Can't Miss. What an incredible palace. And the grounds and fountains are just as spectacular. Again, we were lucky with few people there so we could really see and enjoy everything. There is a market just outside but they did seem to bargain. I got playing cards of Peterhof at a fraction of what they were selling in the palace girftshops.

Jewel In The Russian Crown. No visit to St Petersburg would be complete without coming here. An absolutely stunning palace and gardens, well worth the trip. We came in by land, on a coach, but you can arrive by boat, which might be even better. The approach from the sea, which was how Peter The Great intended his visitors to arrive, is the visual equivalent of "shock & awe". The view up from the sea & its connecting canal, through the bridges & flanking fountains is superb. My other half commented that once the fountains get going (11am each day) the overall effect is more spectacular than Versailles. The grounds are full of buildings, walkways, bowers, fountains. The house itself is very impressive, both inside & out. When you see the black & white photos of the state of the place at the end of WW2, it is a massive testament to the work of the restorers. A definite must-see.

It deserves the comparison to the Versailles. Peterhof, Peter the Great's Palace, is a UNESCO world heritage site. The palace and the grand cascade are the centerpiece of the palace; a magnificent confection of gold, fountains and gardens. The grand cascade is truly a sight to behold, with all of its fountains driven only by gravity. The Samson fountain is considered a masterpiece as well as symbolically important to Russia. The huge lower gardens are interspersed with trick fountains designed to douse the monarchy's guests (and amuse him). Don't miss the Monplaisir palace, which Peter built for himself (he wasn't the gilded type). Take a day to walk around the palace because it's a relaxing experience to be surrounded by so much green and beauty. Besides, you came a long way to see it. Ferries are available for going back to St Petersburg by sea.
Gardens of Peterhof. We only saw the gardens but they were beautiful if rather crowded. Our guide was very knowledgable and negotiated the crowds. The water features were suberb
Keep walking. Make sure that you bring plenty of time and that you have good walking shoes. Take the speedboat to Peterhof highly recommend to buy the boat ticket in advance

Gardens and fountains. We arrived by hydrofoil, on a sunny Monday, the palace was closed for cleaning but the gardens were stunning with the many fountains and statues. The history about how the statues were protected and hidden during the war was interesting.The toilet block we used was busy with a long queue. The view from the palace over the golden statues and water feature was worth the effort. A great place to end our tour of St Petersburg.

Go there. Go there just have a glimpse into the life style of the last of the last emperors of Russia.It has beautiful gardens with the Baltic sea just after they end.The living quarters are an insight into how the high and mighty lived in those days and in contrast how the low lived too. Of course today almost everyone lives like how the high lived in those days.

Amazing views but I have a few tips!. The fountains and gardens are amazingly beautiful. It's a must see in st Petersburg. Tips:Buy a ticket to enter the gardens. (This ticket office is the first one you will see when arriving and approaching the main entrance)After that you can purchase tickets to enter the underground passage (the fountains mechanism) the palace and the church each ticket is bought in its own ticket office. All signs are in Russian so if you don't speak the language it's importante to know that the palace has a specific time in the day for foreign visitors. The ticket office for foreign visitors is inside the palace and they as well can be bought in a specific time frame. Make sure to ask. When we visited, the time for foreigners to visit the palace was from 2:30pm to 4 pm. Not sure if it's the same all year round.

Beautifully renovated palace and fountains. All nice, richly decorated, very crowdy with groups. The fountains starting at 11:00. Picturesque.Public bus goes zo Peterhof from the metro, ticket cost 28 RUB from the conductor. We been ripped off, the conductor charged double fee, still cheaper than any other transport options.

Take a boat. The way to get there is by hovercraft from the city, there's nothing better than this trip on a good sunny day. These boats have been running for nearly 50 years but are still as relevant and cool as they were back then
A must in St. Petersburg . We were on a tour with our cruise. Loved the fountains and gardens. And of course the palace is amazing. A must see for sure.

Excellent museum in Russeum. A lot of valuable original oil paintings can be seen here. There were rooms after rooms of paintings in the museum. Statues were were centralized on the ground floor rooms. Expect a lot of people around you. Picture taking are allowed with no flash used.
Go Early. The Fountains start working at 11am every morning,and the starting of the water jets are very interesting.Don't miss it.Be punctual.

Needs to get it together. A beautiful palace, incredible gardens and architecture, the fountains and waterways take your breath away but there is no possible way to admire it as it should with the amount of tourists it is receiving - nothing against them as I am one of them, but it was truly packed, suffocating at times, our guide could not be heard of so much noise being made by the tourist that do not have any respect

Fountains, fountains, fountains. Over the top spectacular! We were there on a day when it rained and it still was fantastic! The engineering and the artistry were out of this world. My favorite place.

If the Buildings and Grounds don't impress then nothing will!. This was my second time visiting and I am glad that this time it was summer and the fountains were working I think the tour of the inside is impressive but actually the grounds are pretty amazing. You have to wear covers on your shoes because of the intricate and delicate patterns of the wood inlays.

The Fountains, as the locals call it, is amazing!. A great way to spend a beautiful summer day. We took the local bus for a dollar and went to St. Peter and Paul Cathedral first. The upper gardens are free but you need to pay for the rest. The more you see the more you pay. We arrived late do just walked through the lower gardens. Gilt statuary and fountains everywhere! The park is huge with paths leading everywhere and fountains hidden all over. The ice cream is overpriced and they didn't have a hydrofoil scheduled to return so we took the bus back. Also, they turn the fountains off after 6 so be sure you get there when they're on. Also, don't miss the statue where you try to throw money in his boots.

Peter the Great Indeed!. You can visit the gardens and the outside of the original one-story retreat before walking over to the larger palace. At 11:00 exactly every day the Russian National Anthem is played and then the fountains are turned on in succession. It is great! And then you go inside! WOW! The rooms are incredibly impressive and opulent.

Only visited the gardens but lovely. We had decided to go by hydrofoil, and got early to the dock. However, I had read that sometimes the hydrofoils can't sail due to wind, waves etc. It was a bit windy and choppy the day we went. So as not to risk missing fountains being turned on due to the hydrofoil not operating and having to catch the bus, we went straight to the bus stop.Bus took a bit less than 1 hr and we joined the masses at the ticket window. Once in the grounds we saw the massive ticket queues to get tickets to the palace and decided against it. We had already visited Versailles on a previous visit and didn't want to go through that crowd-pressing experience this time. So we just visited the gardens instead.We really enjoyed the gardens. Our enjoyment was a bit limited by the fact that it was a cold and pretty windy day. Nonetheless, while not in the class of Versailles, these gardens were very beautiful.While walking around the gardens we noticed people who were coming from the hydrofoil. So we decided to return that way. Guess what? The travel gods were not on our side that day, and the boat was now closed due to weather.Still, we noticed an old church near the bus stop and went in to have a look. We climbed up to the tower. A nice experience to end the visit and compensate for the hydrofoil disappointment.Tip: Don't rely on the hydrofoil - especially if you are keen to see the fountains begin (worth it). I guess, do as we did and use the bus and hope to return by hydrofoil.

A Must-See Day Trip. We visited on Peterhof on a beautiful June day that most of the palaces at Peterhof were closed, but my friend (an American expat who's lived in St Petesburg for 7 years) said that the gardens are the best part. Since we were seeing a number of other Russian museums on our trip, we didn't feel like we were missing anything. And since the weather was great for a picnic, we brought lunch with us and ate on the beach of the Gulf of Finland. A head's up: The folks who run Peterhof don't really like it when you sit on the grass or in the open where most of the tourist are coming and going, but they ignored us and others sitting and eating on the beach just off the main path. Also, it was a bit chillier than in St Petersburg, especially at the end of the canal, where the water pours into the Gulf. We were glad we brought layers and jackets!That said, I highly recommend making Peterhof a day-trip, or at least half a day. Once you've been impressed by the Summer Palace and awed by the Grand Cascade, the gardens encourage a child-like wonder. They are best appreciated by wandering around to make little discoveries of beauty (Pyramid Fountain, the aviaries, Monplaisir Palace, etc.) and fun (Checkerboard Hill, "trick fountains,"etc.). My friend, my husband and I were all thoroughly exhausted at the end of the day, but it was so worth it!

An All Day Outing. I was amazed by how the textures of the land melded into one another. Peterhof State Museum Preserve is a wonderful bit of land next to the ocean and it lends itself to day-dreaming. If you like watching 'Period' dramas then you will have no trouble imagining that you are taking a stroll on your own bit of land with your palace not far behind. The waterfalls create such a wonderful spectacle and you simply must wow your social media friends by posing a photo of yourself posing in front of them with the Palace as the back drop. It took about an hour and a half on the Metro and then mini bus one way. Enjoy!

Astonishingly beautiful....don't miss it. We loved the fountains - which all spout water to the same level - the amount of decorative detail in the rooms, from the fabric wallpaper with matching chairs and curtains, of course, to the gold leaf everywhere and the parquetry flooring. Excessive and over the top, but still a must see!! We went by ourselves and found it difficult to get tickets to the park and the palace as everything is in Russian, and the lady selling tickets didn't speak English. So we had to buy tickets inside to the palace. The system could be improved so much for tourists. The hydrofoil ride to the palace is good to do...just make sure you take cash because they don't take credit card
Very crowded!. The garden are marvelous to walk through, but visiting the interior in an excercise in tolerance as there is a lot of pushing from the hords of tourists.

Uncomfortable!. Okay, this place is stunning! The fountains, the gardens, the palace. BUT, it was so warm and so crowded that one could barely breathe. Inside the palace, it was jammed with too many people. It was tedious to work our way through the stifling hot rooms. If they'd opened the windows it might have been bearable. The Russians are not very hospitable and make you feel like they're breathing down your neck. They don't smile and they nearly attack when someone steps out of line. No photos are allowed inside this palace. I couldn't wait to get out. I recommend going on a weekday when it's not so crowded.

Beautiful Gardens. We did not go inside the palace, but admired it from the outside. The gardens, and most of all the fountains are the main attraction. DO NOT step on the grass or a whistle will be blown in your face.

Nice museum and garden. I recommend the hydrofoil to reach peterhof, it departs in front of admiralty and takes about 35 min. Company name is peterhof express. Round trip costs 1200 rub. You have to set your return time when buying your ticket. This is nonsense, the return ticket should be open. You directly enter to the lower garden, the garden is beautiful with different kind of fountains. Inside of museum is amazing as well. This is a must visit for saint petersburg visitors.

A must see. Any trip to St Petersburg would not be complete without a stop here. One of the best Museums on earth. If you enjoyed The Sistine Chapel you will also enjoy All That Peterhof has to offer.
Another wonderful Russian museum. This is spectacular even if it is more on a human scale than Tsarskoe selo . I loved the interior - didn't see much of the garden

Busy. A superb entrance. Recommended route is by hydrofoil - taking about 25 minutes.
The palace is designed to be seen from a distance and is sett in well maintained grounds with multiple fountains.
There is so much to see inside the palace.

Peterhof - WOW. If you are in St Petersburg then you have to go.
The building and the Water features are just amazing. Really strong History as the property was completely destroyed after WW2

Peterhof - Russia's Versailles. Peterhof did not fail to impress. A very busy place with everyone walking towards one direction. Security is quite tight. No photos could be taken inside this summer palace of the Russian monarchy. You cannot claim to have been at St Petersburg unless you have stepped into this place. It is Russia's version of their Versailles. It is huge but it not as grand as Versailles. It will awe you thought.

Gold, gold and gold!. There is a lot to see inside the building - artwork, furniture, ceiling decor, tapestries, and so on, but in my view, the emphasis remains to be those golden statutes in the garden. They come in different sizes and shapes, standing on the slope, shining majestically ( goldenly) under the blue sky. At 11.00 am, they all come to life through the fountains of water coming out from them. This is a sight that must not be missed. Even if you cannot find the time for the exhibits inside the palace, or cannot stand the queues and congestion inside the building, you should still come to see the garden.

Don't skip Peterhof. Peterhof was my favorite stop over two days of touring SPB. Of course, it didn't hurt that the weather was perfect, so the gardens and fountains were even more spectacular! We actually never made it inside, but the gardens were alluring enough that it is the top place I would want to return to. If you are touring on your own and the weather is pretty, I would try to take a picnic. Lots of grounds and places for that! Also, there is at least one restaurant on the grounds. We arrived at Peterhof by bus and left by foil boat, which was just a short walk from the palace. I would choose the boat just for shorter travel. Don't miss this beautiful place!
Go by boat to Peterhof. Boat ride to Peterhof is a great way to see panoramic views. Once there, enjoyed picnic in the fantastic gardens, did not make it inside the palace and did not feel deprived.

Spectacular Peterhof. The palace was unbelievably beautiful and spectacular! There were so many huge rooms filled with amazing artwork, furniture, tapestries, personal items, etc., that you find it hard to take it all in. Many room ceilings had such great artwork painted on them that they reminded me of the Vatican and Sistine Chapel. Of course, there was gold everywhere. Gold in the mirrors, in the paint, along the walls, in the furnishings and several rooms were almost 99% gold everything!Outdoor gardens -- front and rear of palace -- were amazing. Fountains, flowers, trees, everywhere. The garden in rear of the palace has a canal that leads down to the sea. The garden is filled with beautiful gold statues, cottages and fountains. At a set time every morning, music begins to play and the fountains come to life and do lovely "dance" to the music. You need to be in garden area at least 15 minutes before the water show begins if you want a good spot to get pics. Beware, though, wind blows the water around and people to close got pretty wet as did their cameras.Luckily, hubby and I went with a tour group, so we actually got early entrance to the palace and did not have to stand in line for tickets. Tour company provided the tickets and has agreement with the palace for their groups to enter the palace before it opens to general public.
A Great Experience. The palace and the grounds with the cascade and fountains are amazing. The best way to get there is to take the hydrofoil.

Peterhof fountains and gardens not to be missed. Must visit by hydrofoil if in St Petersburg. Got there in 1 of the first hydrofoils in the morning before the fountains run. Walk thru the gardens were so serene. And the fountains are spectacular and they all work from gravity, no electricity. But watch your valuables as it gets really, really, crowded.

Queuing, queuing, queuing. Really looked forward to visiting Peterhof. Arrived by hydrofoil and bought an admission ticket then headed to the very, very long queue for Palace/Museum tickets. After 15 minutes we had just progressed a few metres. It appeared it would take 2 hours to get to the ticket office and then a further wait in a queue to actually enter the palace. We gave up and enjoyed the very e the dive fountains and gardens. Did buy tickets and tour through the humble (by royal standards) villa of Monplaisir, Peter the Great's favourite retreat. Cosy with its wood-panelled walls and smaller rooms. Windy when we arrived. By the time we want to leave it's gale force and the hydrofoils and boats have been cancelled. Taxi back to city will cost about $40 or can also get a bus or metro. I am sure Peterhof lives up to the hype. If you choose to go, I recommend joining a tour group or you will waste the day queuing. Not sorry I went, just a bit disappointed at the organisation or lack of it. Good luck when you go.

Peterhof. We didn't go inside the building, as we didn't need to. The lush outdoors was enough. Fountains that flowed from the palace through a canal all the way to the sea. Not just fountains, GOLD fountains with gold statues, huge fountains and manicured landscaping. These Romanovs knew how to live!

Amazing Experience. Cannot believer the scale of the fountains and gardens plus the beautiful palace. Travelled with our own guide, which we organised with the Russian Tourist Board in London, and she was excellent. An amazing experience. Anna made the day really worthwhile. Would really recommend especially in the summer.

It is worth the drive out of town. Do not miss it. It was hard for us to figure out where this palace was as our Viking tour info was not clear. It is not in the fortress of Peter & Paul. The photos of the ruins of Peterhof (after Nazi occupation and desecration) would make anyone so awestruck that such a grand place could be rebuilt in the 20th century. The Russians cherish their heritage to put so much $ into rebuilding this amazing place. The fountains are an amazing piece of engineering with the water being fed in from springs that are 14 miles away, channeled by canals and aqueducts. Fountains go on at 11 AM for a few hours. The statues are covered in gold leaf and shine brilliantly in the sun.  We made a special trek to visit the Peter & Paul Cathedral, about 3 blocks outside of the palace grounds. A service was underway-- the chanting was angelic.
ost beautiful gardens and fountains. I was astounded by the brilliance and vision of Peter The Great. I can't wait to read more about the family.

A World Heritage Site and monument to The Czars.. This place is so extensive, yu have to give it time as it has miles of walkways with an infinite display of magnificent fountains and gardens. Our tour was too limited in time to really fully appreciateone of the word's greatest displays of grandeur.

Gold everywhere. Definitely worth visiting this palace. The wooden floors, the gold plated ornaments, fountains as well as the grounds were beautiful! I loved the tulips in bloom. It gets very crowded and for some reason they only have a single width door to enter with no cue for crowd control. We were there before the "season" so I can't imagine how they handle it then. So much was destroyed by the Nazi's and has been restored. We wondered how it "really" looked before the destruction.

Beautiful gardens with shade and plenty of benches. The gardens are very big so even with the huge number of tourists they do not feel too crowded. Walk in either direction along the coast for a couple of minutes and they become very peaceful. A good option on hot sunny days as there is a lot of shade and coastal breeze but almost nowhere to shelter from rain without paying an admission fee. The hydrofoil is a fun way to get there.

Utterly Unforgettable. Peterhof is utterly unforgettable, rivaling Versailles in every way.
